{14, 0} The present document specifies the procedures used by the protocols for mobility management and session management between User Equipment and Mobility Management Entity in the Evolved Packet System.
---

{14, 0} The present document specifies the procedures used by the protocols for mobility management and session management between User Equipment and Mobility Management Entity in the Evolved Packet System.
{14, 1} These protocols belong to the non-access stratum.
---

{15, 0} The EPS Mobility Management protocol defined in the present document provides procedures for the control of mobility when the User Equipment is using the Evolved UMTS Terrestrial Radio Access Network.
---

{15, 0} The EPS Mobility Management protocol defined in the present document provides procedures for the control of mobility when the User Equipment is using the Evolved UMTS Terrestrial Radio Access Network.
{15, 1} The EMM protocol also provides control of security for the NAS protocols.
---

{16, 0} The EPS Session Management protocol defined in the present document provides procedures for the handling of EPS bearer contexts.
---

{16, 0} The EPS Session Management protocol defined in the present document provides procedures for the handling of EPS bearer contexts.
{16, 1} Together with the bearer control provided by the access stratum, this protocol is used for the control of user plane bearers.
---

{17, 0} For both NAS protocols the present document specifies procedures for the support of inter-system mobility between EUTRAN and other 3GPP or non-3GPP access networks:
{18, 0} For inter-system mobility between E-UTRAN and GERAN, UTRAN or NG-RAN, this includes rules for a mapping between parameters and procedures used by the NAS protocols defined in the present document and the NAS protocols specified in 3GPP TS 24.008 [13] for GERAN and UTRAN, and 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] for NG-RAN.
---

{17, 0} For both NAS protocols the present document specifies procedures for the support of inter-system mobility between EUTRAN and other 3GPP or non-3GPP access networks:
{19, 0} For inter-system mobility between E-UTRAN and generic non-3GPP access networks, this includes specific NAS procedures to maintain IP connectivity to the PDN Gateway and to provide parameters needed by the UE when using mobility management based on Dual-Stack Mobile IPv6 or MIPv4.
---

{20, 0} The present document is applicable to the UE and to the Mobility Management Entity in the EPS.
---

{21, 0} The present document is also applicable to the relay node in the EPS.
---

{22, 0} The present document also specifies NAS signalling enhancement for the support of efficient transport of IP, non-IP, Ethernet and SMS data of CIoT capable devices.
---

{25, 0} References are either specific or nonspecific.
---

{24, 0} The following documents contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of the present document.
{26, 0} For a specific reference, subsequent revisions do not apply.
---

{27, 0} For a non-specific reference, the latest version applies.
---

{24, 0} The following documents contain provisions which, through reference in this text, constitute provisions of the present document.
{27, 0} For a non-specific reference, the latest version applies.
{27, 1} In the case of a reference to a 3GPP document, a non-specific reference implicitly refers to the latest version of that document in the same Release as the present document.
---

{30, 0} For the purposes of the present document, the terms and definitions given in 3GPP TR 21.905 [1] and the following apply.
---

{30, 0} For the purposes of the present document, the terms and definitions given in 3GPP TR 21.905 [1] and the following apply.
{30, 1} A term defined in the present document takes precedence over the definition of the same term, if any, in 3GPP TR 21.905 [1].
---

{31, 0} The term "mobile station" in the present document is synonymous with the term "user equipment" as defined in 3GPP TR 21.905 [1].
---

{32, 0} 1x CS fallback capable UE: A UE that uses a CS infrastructure for a voice call and other CS-domain services by falling back to cdma2000® 1x access network if the UE is served by EUTRAN when a CS service is requested.
---

{33, 0} 5G-EA: 5GS encryption algorithms.
---

{33, 0} 5G-EA: 5GS encryption algorithms.
{33, 1} The term 5G-EA, 5G-EA0, 128-5G-EA1-3 and 5G-EA4-7 used in the present document corresponds to the term NEA, NEA0, NEA1-3 and NEA4-7 defined in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
---

{34, 0} 5G-IA: 5GS integrity algorithms.
---

{34, 0} 5G-IA: 5GS integrity algorithms.
{34, 1} The term 5G-IA, 5G-IA0, 128-5G-IA1-3 and 5G-IA4-7 used in the present document corresponds to the term NIA, NIA0, NIA1-3 and NIA4-7 defined in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
---

{35, 0} Aggregate maximum bit rate: The maximum bit rate that limits the aggregate bit rate of a set of non-GBR bearers of a UE.
---

{35, 0} Aggregate maximum bit rate: The maximum bit rate that limits the aggregate bit rate of a set of non-GBR bearers of a UE.
{35, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{36, 0} APN based congestion control: Congestion control in session management where the network can reject session management requests from UEs or deactivate PDN connections when the associated APN is congested.
---

{37, 0} Attached for emergency bearer services: A UE is attached for emergency bearer services if it has only a PDN connection for emergency bearer services established.
---

{38, 0} Attached for access to RLOS: A UE is attached for access to RLOS if the UE requested access to RLOS during the attach procedure and has a PDN connection for RLOS established after completion of attach procedure.
---

{39, 0} Chosen PLMN: The same as selected PLMN as specified in 3GPP TS 23.122 [6].
---

{40, 0} Control plane CIoT EPS optimization: signalling optimizations to enable efficient transport of user data over control plane via the MME including optional header compression of IP data.
---

{41, 0} User plane CIoT EPS optimization: signalling optimizations to enable efficient transport of user data over the user plane.
---

{42, 0} UE supporting CIoT EPS optimizations: A UE that supports control plane CIoT EPS optimization or user plane CIoT EPS optimization and one or more other CIoT EPS optimizations when the UE is in S1 mode.
---

{43, 0} Attached for EPS services with CP-CIoT EPS optimization: A UE supporting CIoT EPS optimizations is attached for EPS services, and control plane CIoT EPS optimization along with one or more other CIoT EPS optimizations have been accepted by the network.
---

{44, 0} Attached for EPS services with User plane CIoT EPS optimization: A UE supporting CIoT EPS optimizations is attached for EPS services, and user plane CIoT EPS optimization along with one or more other CIoT EPS optimizations have been accepted by the network.
---

{45, 0} Attached for EPS services with CIoT EPS optimization: A UE is attached for EPS services with CP-CIoT EPS optimization or attached for EPS services with user plane CIoT EPS optimization.
---

{46, 0} CS fallback cancellation request: A request received from the MM sublayer to cancel a mobile originating CS fallback.
---

{47, 0} CS fallback capable UE: A UE that uses a CS infrastructure for a voice call and other CS-domain services by falling back to A/Gb or Iu mode if the UE is served by EUTRAN when a CS service is requested.
---

{48, 0} CSG cell: A cell in which only members of the CSG can get normal service.
---

{48, 0} CSG cell: A cell in which only members of the CSG can get normal service.
{48, 1} Depending on local regulation, the CSG cell can provide emergency bearer services also to subscribers who are not member of the CSG.
---

{48, 0} CSG cell: A cell in which only members of the CSG can get normal service.
{48, 1} Depending on local regulation, the CSG cell can provide emergency bearer services also to subscribers who are not member of the CSG.
{48, 2} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{49, 0} CSG ID: A CSG ID is a unique identifier within the scope of one PLMN defined in 3GPP TS 23.003 [2] which identifies a Closed Subscriber Group in the PLMN associated with a cell or group of cells to which access is restricted to members of the CSG.
---

{50, 0} CSG selection: A UE supporting CSG selection selects CSG cell either automatically based on the list of allowed CSG identities or manually based on user selection of CSG on indication of list of available CSGs.
---

{50, 0} CSG selection: A UE supporting CSG selection selects CSG cell either automatically based on the list of allowed CSG identities or manually based on user selection of CSG on indication of list of available CSGs.
{50, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.122 [6].
---

{51, 0} Dedicated bearer: An EPS bearer that is associated with uplink packet filters in the UE and downlink packet filters in the PDN GW where the filters only match certain packets.
---

{51, 0} Dedicated bearer: An EPS bearer that is associated with uplink packet filters in the UE and downlink packet filters in the PDN GW where the filters only match certain packets.
{51, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{52, 0} Default bearer: An EPS bearer that gets established with every new PDN connection.
---

{52, 0} Default bearer: An EPS bearer that gets established with every new PDN connection.
{52, 1} Its context remains established throughout the lifetime of that PDN connection.
---

{52, 0} Default bearer: An EPS bearer that gets established with every new PDN connection.
{52, 1} Its context remains established throughout the lifetime of that PDN connection.
{52, 2} A default EPS bearer is a non-GBR bearer.
---

{52, 0} Default bearer: An EPS bearer that gets established with every new PDN connection.
{52, 1} Its context remains established throughout the lifetime of that PDN connection.
{52, 2} A default EPS bearer is a non-GBR bearer.
{52, 3} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{53, 0} Emergency EPS bearer context: A default EPS bearer context which was activated with request type "emergency" or "handover of emergency bearer services", or any dedicated EPS bearer context associated to this default EPS bearer context.
---

{54, 0} EMM context: An EMM context is established in the UE and the MME when an attach procedure is successfully completed.
---

{55, 0} EMM-CONNECTED mode: A UE is in EMM-CONNECTED mode when a NAS signalling connection between UE and network is established.
---

{55, 0} EMM-CONNECTED mode: A UE is in EMM-CONNECTED mode when a NAS signalling connection between UE and network is established.
{55, 1} The term EMM-CONNECTED mode used in the present document corresponds to the term ECM-CONNECTED state used in 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{56, 0} EMM-IDLE mode: A UE is in EMM-IDLE mode when no NAS signalling connection between UE and network exists or when RRC connection suspend has been indicated by lower layers.
---

{56, 0} EMM-IDLE mode: A UE is in EMM-IDLE mode when no NAS signalling connection between UE and network exists or when RRC connection suspend has been indicated by lower layers.
{56, 1} The term EMM-IDLE mode used in the present document corresponds to the term ECM-IDLE state used in 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{57, 0} EPS security context: In the present specification, EPS security context is used as a synonym for EPS NAS security context specified in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19].
---

{58, 0} EPS services: Services provided by PS domain.
---

{58, 0} EPS services: Services provided by PS domain.
{58, 1} Within the context of this specification, EPS services is used as a synonym for GPRS services in 3GPP TS 24.008 [13].
---

{59, 0} Evolved packet core network: The successor to the 3GPP Release 7 packet-switched core network, developed by 3GPP within the framework of the 3GPP System Architecture Evolution.
---

{60, 0} Evolved packet system: The evolved packet system or evolved 3GPP packet-switched domain consists of the evolved packet core network and the evolved universal terrestrial radio access network.
---

{60, 0} Evolved packet system: The evolved packet system or evolved 3GPP packet-switched domain consists of the evolved packet core network and the evolved universal terrestrial radio access network.
{60, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{61, 0} GBR bearer: An EPS bearer that uses dedicated network resources related to a guaranteed bit rate value, which are permanently allocated at EPS bearer establishment/modification.
---

{61, 0} GBR bearer: An EPS bearer that uses dedicated network resources related to a guaranteed bit rate value, which are permanently allocated at EPS bearer establishment/modification.
{61, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{62, 0} General NAS level mobility management congestion control: The type of congestion control that is applied at a general overload or congestion situation in the network, e.g. lack of processing resources.
---

{63, 0} Group specific session management congestion control: Type of congestion control at session management level that is applied to reject session management requests from UEs belonging to a particular group when one or more group congestion criteria as specified in 3GPP TS 23.401 [10] are met.
---

{64, 0} Highest ranked ACDC category: The ACDC category with the lowest value as defined in 3GPP TS 24.105 [35].
---

{65, 0} Initial NAS message: A NAS message is considered as an initial NAS message, if this NAS message can trigger the establishment of a NAS signalling connection.
---

{65, 0} Initial NAS message: A NAS message is considered as an initial NAS message, if this NAS message can trigger the establishment of a NAS signalling connection.
{65, 1} For instance, the ATTACH REQUEST message is an initial NAS message.
---

{66, 0} IPv4v6 capability: Capability of the IP stack associated with a UE to support a dual stack configuration with both an IPv4 address and an IPv6 address allocated.
---

{67, 0} Kilobit: 1000 bits.
---

{68, 0} Last Visited Registered TAI: A TAI which is contained in the TAI list that the UE registered to the network and which identifies the tracking area last visited by the UE.
---

{69, 0} Linked Bearer Identity: This identity indicates to which default bearer the additional bearer resource is linked.
---

{70, 0} LIPA PDN connection: A PDN connection, for which the default EPS bearer context or default PDP context was activated with an APN authorized to use LIPA.
---

{70, 0} LIPA PDN connection: A PDN connection, for which the default EPS bearer context or default PDP context was activated with an APN authorized to use LIPA.
{70, 1} The network authorizes an APN for using LIPA based on the subscription profile and subsequently the network considers this PDN connection a LIPA PDN connection.
---

{71, 0} Lower layer failure: A failure reported by the AS to the NAS that cannot be corrected on AS level.
---

{71, 0} Lower layer failure: A failure reported by the AS to the NAS that cannot be corrected on AS level.
{71, 1} When the AS indicates a lower layer failure to NAS, the NAS signalling connection is not available.
---

{72, 0} Mapped EPS security context: A mapped security context to be used in EPS.
---

{72, 0} Mapped EPS security context: A mapped security context to be used in EPS.
{72, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 33.401 [19].
---

{73, 0} Mapped GUTI: A GUTI which is mapped from a P-TMSI and an RAI allocated previously by an SGSN.
---

{73, 0} Mapped GUTI: A GUTI which is mapped from a P-TMSI and an RAI allocated previously by an SGSN.
{73, 1} Mapping rules are defined in 3GPP TS 23.003 [2].
---

{73, 0} Mapped GUTI: A GUTI which is mapped from a P-TMSI and an RAI allocated previously by an SGSN.
{73, 1} Mapping rules are defined in 3GPP TS 23.003 [2].
{73, 2} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{74, 0} Megabit: 1,000,000 bits.
---

{75, 0} Message header: A standard L3 message header as defined in 3GPP TS 24.007 [12].
---

{76, 0} MME area: An area containing tracking areas served by an MME.
---

{77, 0} MO MMTEL voice call is started: the MO-MMTEL-voice-started indication was received from upper layers and after reception of the MO-MMTEL-voice-started indication, the MO-MMTEL-voice-ended indication has not been received.
---

{78, 0} MO MMTEL video call is started: the MO-MMTEL-video-started indication was received from upper layers and after reception of the MO-MMTEL-video-started indication, the MO-MMTEL-video-ended indication has not been received.
---

{79, 0} MO SMSoIP is started: the MO-SMSoIP-attempt-started indication was received from upper layers and after reception of the MO-SMSoIP-attempt-started indication, the MO-SMSoIP-attempt-ended indication has not been received.
---

{80, 0} NAS level mobility management congestion control: Congestion control mechanism in the network in mobility management. "
---

{80, 0} NAS level mobility management congestion control: Congestion control mechanism in the network in mobility management. "
{80, 1} NAS level mobility management congestion control" consists of "subscribed APN based congestion control" and "general NAS level mobility management congestion control".
---

{81, 0} NAS signalling connection: A peer to peer S1 mode connection between UE and MME.
---

{81, 0} NAS signalling connection: A peer to peer S1 mode connection between UE and MME.
{81, 1} A NAS signalling connection consists of the concatenation of an RRC connection via the "LTE-Uu" interface and an S1AP connection via the S1 interface.
---

{81, 0} NAS signalling connection: A peer to peer S1 mode connection between UE and MME.
{81, 1} A NAS signalling connection consists of the concatenation of an RRC connection via the "LTE-Uu" interface and an S1AP connection via the S1 interface.
{81, 2} Additionally, for the purpose of optimized handover or idle mode mobility from cdma2000® HRPD access to EUTRAN, the NAS signalling connection can consist of a concatenation of an S101AP connection and a signalling tunnel over a cdma2000® HRPD access network.
---

{82, 0} NAS signalling connection recovery: A mechanism initiated by the NAS to restore the NAS signalling connection on indication of "RRC connection failure" by the lower layers.
---

{83, 0} Native GUTI: A GUTI previously allocated by an MME.
---

{83, 0} Native GUTI: A GUTI previously allocated by an MME.
{83, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{84, 0} Non-access stratum protocols: The protocols between UE and MSC or SGSN that are not terminated in the UTRAN, and the protocols between UE and MME that are not terminated in the E-UTRAN.
---

{84, 0} Non-access stratum protocols: The protocols between UE and MSC or SGSN that are not terminated in the UTRAN, and the protocols between UE and MME that are not terminated in the E-UTRAN.
{84, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TR 21.905 [1].
---

{85, 0} Non-emergency EPS bearer context: Any EPS bearer context which is not an emergency EPS bearer context.
---

{86, 0} Non-EPS services: Services provided by CS domain.
---

{86, 0} Non-EPS services: Services provided by CS domain.
{86, 1} Within the context of this specification, non-EPS services is used as a synonym for non-GPRS services in 3GPP TS 24.008 [13].
---

{86, 0} Non-EPS services: Services provided by CS domain.
{86, 1} Within the context of this specification, non-EPS services is used as a synonym for non-GPRS services in 3GPP TS 24.008 [13].
{86, 2} A UE which camps on E-UTRAN can attach to both EPS services and non-EPS services.
---

{87, 0} Non-GBR bearer: An EPS bearer that uses network resources that are not related to a guaranteed bit rate value.
---

{87, 0} Non-GBR bearer: An EPS bearer that uses network resources that are not related to a guaranteed bit rate value.
{87, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{88, 0} PDN address: An IP address assigned to the UE by the Packet Data Network Gateway.
---

{89, 0} PDN connection for emergency bearer services: A PDN connection for which the default EPS bearer context or default PDP context was activated with request type "emergency" or "handover of emergency bearer services".
---

{90, 0} PDN connection for RLOS: A PDN connection for which the default EPS bearer context was activated with request type "RLOS".
---

{91, 0} Plain NAS message: A NAS message with a header including neither a message authentication code nor a sequence number.
---

{92, 0} Persistent EPS bearer context: either a non-emergency EPS bearer context representing a GBR bearer with QoS equivalent to QoS of teleservice 11 and where there is a radio bearer associated with that context, or an emergency EPS bearer context where there is a radio bearer associated with that context.
---

{93, 0} Procedure Transaction Identity: An identity which is dynamically allocated by the UE for the UE requested ESM procedures.
---

{93, 0} Procedure Transaction Identity: An identity which is dynamically allocated by the UE for the UE requested ESM procedures.
{93, 1} The procedure transaction identity is released when the procedure is completed.
---

{94, 0} RAT-related TMSI: When the UE is camping on an E-UTRAN cell, the RAT-related TMSI is the GUTI; when it is camping on a GERAN or UTRAN cell, the RAT-related TMSI is the P-TMSI.
---

{95, 0} Registered PLMN: The PLMN on which the UE is registered.
---

{95, 0} Registered PLMN: The PLMN on which the UE is registered.
{95, 1} The identity of the registered PLMN is provided to the UE within the GUTI.
---

{96, 0} Relay node: A network element in the E-UTRAN, wirelessly connected to an eNode B and providing relaying function to UEs served by the E-UTRAN.
---

{96, 0} Relay node: A network element in the E-UTRAN, wirelessly connected to an eNode B and providing relaying function to UEs served by the E-UTRAN.
{96, 1} Definition derived from 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{97, 0} Removal of eCall only mode restriction: All the limitations as described in 3GPP TS 22.101 [46] for the eCall only mode do not apply any more.
---

{98, 0} RLOS EPS bearer context: A default RLOS EPS bearer context which was activated with request type "RLOS", or any dedicated EPS bearer context associated to this default EPS bearer context.
---

{99, 0} The label indicates that this subclause or paragraph applies only to a system which operates in S1 mode, i.e. with a functional division that is in accordance with the use of an S1 interface between the radio access network and the core network.
---

{99, 0} The label indicates that this subclause or paragraph applies only to a system which operates in S1 mode, i.e. with a functional division that is in accordance with the use of an S1 interface between the radio access network and the core network.
{99, 1} The S1 mode includes WB-S1 mode and NB-S1 mode.
---

{99, 0} The label indicates that this subclause or paragraph applies only to a system which operates in S1 mode, i.e. with a functional division that is in accordance with the use of an S1 interface between the radio access network and the core network.
{99, 1} The S1 mode includes WB-S1 mode and NB-S1 mode.
{99, 2} In a multi-access system this case is determined by the current serving radio access network.
---

{100, 0} In NB-S1 mode: Indicates this paragraph applies only to a system which operates in NB-S1 mode.
---

{100, 0} In NB-S1 mode: Indicates this paragraph applies only to a system which operates in NB-S1 mode.
{100, 1} For a multi-access system this case applies if the current serving radio access network provides access to network services via E-UTRA by NB-IoT.
---

{101, 0} In WB-S1 mode: Indicates this paragraph applies only to a system which operates in WB-S1 mode.
---

{101, 0} In WB-S1 mode: Indicates this paragraph applies only to a system which operates in WB-S1 mode.
{101, 1} For a multi-access system this case applies if the system operates in S1 mode, but not in NB-S1 mode.
---

{102, 0} In WB-S1/CE mode: Indicates this paragraph applies only when a UE, which is a CE mode B capable UE, is operating in CE mode A or B in WB-S1 mode.
---

{103, 0} SCEF PDN Connection: A PDN connection established between the UE and the Service Capability Exposure Function for transmitting the UE's non-IP data related to a specific application.
---

{104, 0} SGi PDN Connection: A PDN connection established between the UE and the Packet Gateway for transmitting the UE's IP, non-IP or Ethernet data related to a specific application.
---

{105, 0} S101 mode: Applies to a system that operates with a functional division that is in accordance with the use of an S101 interface.
---

{105, 0} S101 mode: Applies to a system that operates with a functional division that is in accordance with the use of an S101 interface.
{105, 1} For the definition of the S101 reference point, see 3GPP TS 23.402 [11].
---

{106, 0} SIPTO at the local network PDN connection: A PDN connection, for which the default EPS bearer context or default PDP context was activated with an APN authorized to use SIPTO at the local network and it was activated such that the traffic of the PDN connection will be using an L-GW.
---

{106, 0} SIPTO at the local network PDN connection: A PDN connection, for which the default EPS bearer context or default PDP context was activated with an APN authorized to use SIPTO at the local network and it was activated such that the traffic of the PDN connection will be using an L-GW.
{106, 1} The network authorizes an APN for using SIPTO at the local network based on the subscription profile and subsequently the network considers this PDN connection a SIPTO at the local network PDN connection.
---

{106, 0} SIPTO at the local network PDN connection: A PDN connection, for which the default EPS bearer context or default PDP context was activated with an APN authorized to use SIPTO at the local network and it was activated such that the traffic of the PDN connection will be using an L-GW.
{106, 1} The network authorizes an APN for using SIPTO at the local network based on the subscription profile and subsequently the network considers this PDN connection a SIPTO at the local network PDN connection.
{106, 2} SIPTO at the local network PDN connection can be of IP, non-IP or Ethernet PDN type.
---

{107, 0} SIPTO at the local network PDN connection with a collocated L-GW: A SIPTO at the local network PDN connection which is established to a L-GW function collocated with the NodeB. The core-network entity can be aware of whether the SIPTO at the local network PDN connection with a collocated L-GW is used when the PDN connection is established.
---

{108, 0} SIPTO at the local network PDN connection with a stand-alone GW: A SIPTO at the local network PDN connection which is established to a stand-alone GW.
---

{108, 0} SIPTO at the local network PDN connection with a stand-alone GW: A SIPTO at the local network PDN connection which is established to a stand-alone GW.
{108, 1} The core-network entity can be aware of whether the SIPTO at the local network PDN connection with a stand-alone GW is used when the PDN connection is established.
---

{109, 0} "SMS only": A subset of services which includes only Short Message Service.
---

{109, 0} "SMS only": A subset of services which includes only Short Message Service.
{109, 1} A UE camping on E-UTRAN can attach to both EPS services and "SMS only".
---

{110, 0} SMS over NAS: refers to SMS in MME or SMS over SGs.
---

{111, 0} SMS over S102: refers to SMS which uses 1xCS procedures in EPS as defined in 3GPP TS 23.272 [9].
---

{112, 0} Subscribed APN based congestion control: Congestion control in mobility management where the network can reject attach requests from UEs with a certain APN in the subscription.
---

{113, 0} TAI list: A list of TAIs that identify the tracking areas that the UE can enter without performing a tracking area updating procedure.
---

{113, 0} TAI list: A list of TAIs that identify the tracking areas that the UE can enter without performing a tracking area updating procedure.
{113, 1} The TAIs in a TAI list assigned by an MME to a UE pertain to the same MME area.
---

{114, 0} Traffic flow aggregate: A temporary aggregate of packet filters that are included in a UE requested bearer resource allocation procedure or a UE requested bearer resource modification procedure and that is inserted into a traffic flow template for an EPS bearer context by the network once the UE requested bearer resource allocation procedure or UE requested bearer resource modification procedure is completed.
---

{115, 0} UE configured for dual priority: A UE which provides dual priority support is configured for NAS signalling low priority and also configured to override the NAS signalling low priority indicator.
---

{116, 0} UE configured to use AC11 – 15 in selected PLMN: A UE configured with at least one access class in the range 11-15 on the USIM, and the access class is applicable in the selected PLMN according to 3GPP TS 22.011 [1A].
---

{117, 0} UE's availability for voice calls in the IMS: The indication of this availability or non-availability is provided by the upper layers of the UE as specified in 3GPP TS 24.229 [13D] in the annex relevant to the IP-Connectivity Access Network in use or determined in the NAS layer, as specified in subclause 4.3.1.
---

{117, 0} UE's availability for voice calls in the IMS: The indication of this availability or non-availability is provided by the upper layers of the UE as specified in 3GPP TS 24.229 [13D] in the annex relevant to the IP-Connectivity Access Network in use or determined in the NAS layer, as specified in subclause 4.3.1.
{117, 1} If availability is indicated, the UE uses the IM CN Subsystem and can terminate or originate requests for SIP sessions including an audio component with codecs suited for voice.
---

{118, 0} UE's usage setting: This is a UE setting that indicates whether the UE has preference for voice services over data services or vice-versa.
---

{118, 0} UE's usage setting: This is a UE setting that indicates whether the UE has preference for voice services over data services or vice-versa.
{118, 1} If a UE has preference for voice services, then the UE's usage setting is "voice centric".
---

{118, 0} UE's usage setting: This is a UE setting that indicates whether the UE has preference for voice services over data services or vice-versa.
{118, 1} If a UE has preference for voice services, then the UE's usage setting is "voice centric".
{118, 2} If a UE has preference for data services, then the UE's usage setting is "data centric".
---

{118, 0} UE's usage setting: This is a UE setting that indicates whether the UE has preference for voice services over data services or vice-versa.
{118, 1} If a UE has preference for voice services, then the UE's usage setting is "voice centric".
{118, 2} If a UE has preference for data services, then the UE's usage setting is "data centric".
{118, 3} A UE whose setting is "data centric" may still require access to voice services.
---

{118, 0} UE's usage setting: This is a UE setting that indicates whether the UE has preference for voice services over data services or vice-versa.
{118, 1} If a UE has preference for voice services, then the UE's usage setting is "voice centric".
{118, 2} If a UE has preference for data services, then the UE's usage setting is "data centric".
{118, 3} A UE whose setting is "data centric" may still require access to voice services.
{118, 4} A UE whose setting is "voice centric" may still require access to data services.
---

{118, 0} UE's usage setting: This is a UE setting that indicates whether the UE has preference for voice services over data services or vice-versa.
{118, 1} If a UE has preference for voice services, then the UE's usage setting is "voice centric".
{118, 2} If a UE has preference for data services, then the UE's usage setting is "data centric".
{118, 3} A UE whose setting is "data centric" may still require access to voice services.
{118, 4} A UE whose setting is "voice centric" may still require access to data services.
{118, 5} This definition is derived from 3GPP TS 23.221 [8A] and it applies to voice capable UEs.
---

{118, 0} UE's usage setting: This is a UE setting that indicates whether the UE has preference for voice services over data services or vice-versa.
{118, 1} If a UE has preference for voice services, then the UE's usage setting is "voice centric".
{118, 2} If a UE has preference for data services, then the UE's usage setting is "data centric".
{118, 3} A UE whose setting is "data centric" may still require access to voice services.
{118, 4} A UE whose setting is "voice centric" may still require access to data services.
{118, 5} This definition is derived from 3GPP TS 23.221 [8A] and it applies to voice capable UEs.
{118, 6} If the UE is capable of both S1 mode and N1 mode, there is a single UE's usage setting which applies to both 5GS and EPS.
---

{119, 0} UE using EPS services with control plane CIoT EPS optimization: A UE that is attached for EPS services with the control plane CIOT EPS optimization accepted by the network.

{139, 0} The non-access stratum described in the present document forms the highest stratum of the control plane between UE and MME at the radio interface.
---

{140, 0} Main functions of the protocols that are part of the NAS are, the support of mobility of the user equipment;
---

{140, 0} Main functions of the protocols that are part of the NAS are, the support of session management procedures to establish and maintain IP connectivity between the UE and a packet data network gateway.
---

{143, 0} NAS security is an additional function of the NAS providing services to the NAS protocols, e.g. integrity protection and ciphering of NAS signalling messages.
---

{144, 0} For the support of the above functions, the following procedures are supplied within this specification:
{145, 0} elementary procedures for EPS mobility management in clause 5;
---

{144, 0} For the support of the above functions, the following procedures are supplied within this specification:
{146, 0} elementary procedures for EPS session management in clause 6.
---

{147, 0} Complete NAS transactions consist of specific sequences of elementary procedures.
---

{147, 0} Complete NAS transactions consist of specific sequences of elementary procedures.
{147, 1} Examples of such specific sequences can be found in 3GPP TS 23.401 [10].
---

{148, 0} The NAS for EPS follows the protocol architecture model for layer 3 as described in 3GPP TS 24.007 [12]; however, due to the objective of EPS to provide the subscriber with a "ready-to-use" IP connectivity and an "always-on" experience, the protocol supports a linkage between mobility management and session management procedures during the attach procedure.
---

{149, 0} Signalling procedures for the control of NAS security are described as part of the EPS mobility management in clause 5.
---

{149, 0} Signalling procedures for the control of NAS security are described as part of the EPS mobility management in clause 5.
{149, 1} In addition to that, principles for the handing of EPS security contexts and for the activation of ciphering and integrity protection, when a NAS signalling connection is established, are provided in subclause 4.4.
---

{151, 0} During the EPS attach procedure, the network can activate a default EPS bearer context.
---

{151, 0} During the EPS attach procedure, the network can activate a default EPS bearer context.
{151, 1} Additionally, the network can activate one or several dedicated EPS bearer contexts in parallel for PDN connections of IP or Ethernet PDN type.
---

{151, 0} During the EPS attach procedure, the network can activate a default EPS bearer context.
{151, 1} Additionally, the network can activate one or several dedicated EPS bearer contexts in parallel for PDN connections of IP or Ethernet PDN type.
{151, 2} To this purpose the EPS session management messages for the default EPS bearer context activation can be transmitted in an information element in the EPS mobility management messages.
---

{151, 0} During the EPS attach procedure, the network can activate a default EPS bearer context.
{151, 1} Additionally, the network can activate one or several dedicated EPS bearer contexts in parallel for PDN connections of IP or Ethernet PDN type.
{151, 2} To this purpose the EPS session management messages for the default EPS bearer context activation can be transmitted in an information element in the EPS mobility management messages.
{151, 3} In this case, the UE and the network execute the attach procedure, the default EPS bearer context activation procedure, and the dedicated EPS bearer context activation procedure in parallel.
---

{151, 0} During the EPS attach procedure, the network can activate a default EPS bearer context.
{151, 1} Additionally, the network can activate one or several dedicated EPS bearer contexts in parallel for PDN connections of IP or Ethernet PDN type.
{151, 2} To this purpose the EPS session management messages for the default EPS bearer context activation can be transmitted in an information element in the EPS mobility management messages.
{151, 3} In this case, the UE and the network execute the attach procedure, the default EPS bearer context activation procedure, and the dedicated EPS bearer context activation procedure in parallel.
{151, 4} The UE and network shall complete the combined default EPS bearer context activation procedure and the attach procedure before the dedicated EPS bearer context activation procedure is completed.
---

{151, 0} During the EPS attach procedure, the network can activate a default EPS bearer context.
{151, 1} Additionally, the network can activate one or several dedicated EPS bearer contexts in parallel for PDN connections of IP or Ethernet PDN type.
{151, 2} To this purpose the EPS session management messages for the default EPS bearer context activation can be transmitted in an information element in the EPS mobility management messages.
{151, 3} In this case, the UE and the network execute the attach procedure, the default EPS bearer context activation procedure, and the dedicated EPS bearer context activation procedure in parallel.
{151, 4} The UE and network shall complete the combined default EPS bearer context activation procedure and the attach procedure before the dedicated EPS bearer context activation procedure is completed.
{151, 5} If EMM-REGISTERED without PDN connection is not supported by the UE or the MME, then the success of the attach procedure is dependent on the success of the default EPS bearer context activation procedure.
---

{151, 0} During the EPS attach procedure, the network can activate a default EPS bearer context.
{151, 1} Additionally, the network can activate one or several dedicated EPS bearer contexts in parallel for PDN connections of IP or Ethernet PDN type.
{151, 2} To this purpose the EPS session management messages for the default EPS bearer context activation can be transmitted in an information element in the EPS mobility management messages.
{151, 3} In this case, the UE and the network execute the attach procedure, the default EPS bearer context activation procedure, and the dedicated EPS bearer context activation procedure in parallel.
{151, 4} The UE and network shall complete the combined default EPS bearer context activation procedure and the attach procedure before the dedicated EPS bearer context activation procedure is completed.
{151, 5} If EMM-REGISTERED without PDN connection is not supported by the UE or the MME, then the success of the attach procedure is dependent on the success of the default EPS bearer context activation procedure.
{151, 6} If the attach procedure fails, then the ESM procedures also fail.
---

{152, 0} A UE using EPS services with control plane CIoT EPS optimization can initiate transport of user data via the control plane.
---

{152, 0} A UE using EPS services with control plane CIoT EPS optimization can initiate transport of user data via the control plane.
{152, 1} For this purpose a UE in EMM-IDLE mode can initiate the service request procedure and transmit the ESM DATA TRANSPORT message in an information element in the CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message.
---

{153, 0} Except for the attach procedure and the service request procedure, during EMM procedures the MME shall suspend the transmission of ESM messages.
---

{153, 0} Except for the attach procedure and the service request procedure, during EMM procedures the MME shall suspend the transmission of ESM messages.
{153, 1} During the service request procedure the MME may suspend the transmission of ESM messages.
---

{154, 0} Except for the attach procedure and the service request procedure for UE initiated transport of user data via the control plane, during EMM procedures the UE shall suspend the transmission of ESM messages.
---

{156, 0} A UE configured for NAS signalling low priority indicates this by including the Device properties IE in the appropriate NAS message and setting the low priority indicator to "MS is configured for NAS signalling low priority", except for the following cases in which the UE shall set the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority":
{157, 0} the UE is performing an attach for emergency bearer services;
---

{156, 0} A UE configured for NAS signalling low priority indicates this by including the Device properties IE in the appropriate NAS message and setting the low priority indicator to "MS is configured for NAS signalling low priority", except for the following cases in which the UE shall set the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority":
{158, 0} the UE has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services established and is performing EPS mobility management procedures, or is establishing a PDN connection for emergency bearer services;
---

{156, 0} A UE configured for NAS signalling low priority indicates this by including the Device properties IE in the appropriate NAS message and setting the low priority indicator to "MS is configured for NAS signalling low priority", except for the following cases in which the UE shall set the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority":
{159, 0} the UE configured for dual priority is requested by the upper layers to establish a PDN connection with the low priority indicator set to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority";
---

{156, 0} A UE configured for NAS signalling low priority indicates this by including the Device properties IE in the appropriate NAS message and setting the low priority indicator to "MS is configured for NAS signalling low priority", except for the following cases in which the UE shall set the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority":
{160, 0} the UE configured for dual priority is performing EPS session management procedures related to the PDN connection established with low priority indicator set to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority";
---

{156, 0} A UE configured for NAS signalling low priority indicates this by including the Device properties IE in the appropriate NAS message and setting the low priority indicator to "MS is configured for NAS signalling low priority", except for the following cases in which the UE shall set the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority":
{161, 0} the UE configured for dual priority has a PDN connection established by setting the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority" and is performing EPS mobility management procedures;
---

{156, 0} A UE configured for NAS signalling low priority indicates this by including the Device properties IE in the appropriate NAS message and setting the low priority indicator to "MS is configured for NAS signalling low priority", except for the following cases in which the UE shall set the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority":
{162, 0} the UE is performing a service request procedure for a CS fallback emergency call or 1xCS fallback emergency call;
---

{156, 0} A UE configured for NAS signalling low priority indicates this by including the Device properties IE in the appropriate NAS message and setting the low priority indicator to "MS is configured for NAS signalling low priority", except for the following cases in which the UE shall set the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority":
{163, 0} the UE is a UE configured to use AC11 – 15 in selected PLMN;
---

{156, 0} A UE configured for NAS signalling low priority indicates this by including the Device properties IE in the appropriate NAS message and setting the low priority indicator to "MS is configured for NAS signalling low priority", except for the following cases in which the UE shall set the low priority indicator to "MS is not configured for NAS signalling low priority":
{164, 0} the UE is responding to paging.
---

{165, 0} The network may use the NAS signalling low priority indication for NAS level mobility management congestion control and APN based congestion control.
---

{166, 0} If the NAS signalling low priority indication is provided in a PDN CONNECTIVITY REQUEST message, the MME stores the NAS signalling low priority indication within the default EPS bearer context activated due to the PDN connectivity request procedure.

{169, 0} A UE attached for EPS services shall operate in one of the following operation modes:
{170, 0} PS mode 1 of operation: the UE registers only to EPS services, and UE's usage setting is "voice centric";
---

{169, 0} A UE attached for EPS services shall operate in one of the following operation modes:
{171, 0} PS mode 2 of operation: the UE registers only to EPS services, and UE's usage setting is "data centric";
---

{169, 0} A UE attached for EPS services shall operate in one of the following operation modes:
{172, 0} CS/PS mode 1 of operation: the UE registers to both EPS and non-EPS services, and UE's usage setting is "voice centric";
---

{169, 0} A UE attached for EPS services shall operate in one of the following operation modes:
{173, 0} CS/PS mode 2 of operation: the UE registers to both EPS and non-EPS services, and UE's usage setting is "data centric".
---

{174, 0} A UE configured to use CS fallback, shall operate in CS/PS mode 1 or CS/PS mode 2.
---

{174, 0} A UE configured to use CS fallback, shall operate in CS/PS mode 1 or CS/PS mode 2.
{174, 1} Such UE may also be configured to use IMS, in which case the voice domain preference for E-UTRAN as defined in 3GPP TS 24.167 [13B] shall be used for the selection of the domain for originating voice communication services.
---

{175, 0} Upon request from upper layers to establish a CS emergency call, if the UE needs to initiate a CS fallback emergency call but it is unable to perform CS fallback, the UE shall attempt to select GERAN or UTRAN radio access technology, and a UE with "IMS voice not available" should disable the E-UTRA capability to allow a potential callback, and then progress the CS emergency call establishment;
---

{175, 0} Upon request from upper layers to establish a CS emergency call, if the UE needs to initiate a 1xCS fallback emergency call but it is unable to perform 1xCS fallback, the UE shall attempt to select cdma2000® 1x radio access technology to establish the call.
---

{178, 0} A UE configured to use SMS over SGs shall operate in CS/PS mode 1 or CS/PS mode 2.
---

{179, 0} The behaviour of the UE in CS/PS mode 1 of operation, upon failure to access the CS domain or upon reception of a "CS fallback not preferred" or "SMS only" indication, will depend on the availability of voice over IMS.
---

{179, 0} The behaviour of the UE in CS/PS mode 1 of operation, upon failure to access the CS domain or upon reception of a "CS fallback not preferred" or "SMS only" indication, will depend on the availability of voice over IMS.
{179, 1} In the present document, "IMS voice not available" refers to one of the following conditions:
{180, 0} the UE is not configured to use IMS;
---

{179, 0} The behaviour of the UE in CS/PS mode 1 of operation, upon failure to access the CS domain or upon reception of a "CS fallback not preferred" or "SMS only" indication, will depend on the availability of voice over IMS.
{179, 1} In the present document, "IMS voice not available" refers to one of the following conditions:
{181, 0} the UE is not configured to use IMS voice, i.e. when the voice domain preference for E-UTRAN, as defined in 3GPP TS 24.167 [13B], indicates that voice communication services are allowed to be invoked only over the CS domain;
---

{179, 0} The behaviour of the UE in CS/PS mode 1 of operation, upon failure to access the CS domain or upon reception of a "CS fallback not preferred" or "SMS only" indication, will depend on the availability of voice over IMS.
{179, 1} In the present document, "IMS voice not available" refers to one of the following conditions:
{182, 0} the UE is configured to use IMS voice, but the network indicates in the ATTACH ACCEPT message or the TRACKING AREA UPDATE ACCEPT message that IMS voice over PS sessions are not supported;
---

{179, 0} The behaviour of the UE in CS/PS mode 1 of operation, upon failure to access the CS domain or upon reception of a "CS fallback not preferred" or "SMS only" indication, will depend on the availability of voice over IMS.
{179, 1} In the present document, "IMS voice not available" refers to one of the following conditions:
{183, 0} the UE is configured to use IMS voice, the network indicates in the ATTACH ACCEPT message or the TRACKING AREA UPDATE ACCEPT message that IMS voice over PS sessions are supported, but the upper layers, provide no indication that the UE is available for voice call in the IMS within a manufacturer determined period of time;
---

{179, 0} The behaviour of the UE in CS/PS mode 1 of operation, upon failure to access the CS domain or upon reception of a "CS fallback not preferred" or "SMS only" indication, will depend on the availability of voice over IMS.
{179, 1} In the present document, "IMS voice not available" refers to one of the following conditions:
{183, 0} the UE is configured to use IMS voice, the network indicates in the ATTACH ACCEPT message or the TRACKING AREA UPDATE ACCEPT message that IMS voice over PS sessions are supported, but the upper layers, indicate that the UE is not available for voice calls in the IMS.
---

{186, 0} Other conditions may exist but these are implementation specific.
---

{187, 0} In the present document, "IMS voice available" refers to the conditions a, b, c and d, and other implementation specific conditions for "IMS voice not available" evaluate to false.

{190, 0} The UE mode of operation can change as a result of e.g., a change of UE's usage setting for a CS voice capable UE;
---

{190, 0} The UE mode of operation can change as a result of e.g., a change of voice domain preference for E-UTRAN as defined in 3GPP TS 24.167 [13B] for a CS voice capable UE;
---

{190, 0} The UE mode of operation can change as a result of e.g., a change in the UE's availability for voice calls in the IMS;
---

{190, 0} The UE mode of operation can change as a result of e.g., a change in UE configuration regarding the use of SMS as defined in 3GPP TS 24.167 [13B].

{198, 0} The UE is operating in PS mode 1 or PS mode 2

{206, 0} The UE is operating in PS mode 1

{207, 0} The UE is operating in PS mode 2

{215, 0} This clause describes the principles for the handling of EPS security contexts in the UE and in the MME and the procedures used for the security protection of EPS NAS messages between UE and MME.
---

{215, 0} This clause describes the principles for the handling of EPS security contexts in the UE and in the MME and the procedures used for the security protection of EPS NAS messages between UE and MME.
{215, 1} Security protection involves integrity protection and ciphering of the EMM and ESM NAS messages.
---

{216, 0} The signalling procedures for the control of NAS security are part of the EMM protocol and are described in detail in clause 5.
---

{219, 0} The security parameters for authentication, integrity protection and ciphering are tied together in an EPS security context and identified by a key set identifier for E-UTRAN.
---

{219, 0} The security parameters for authentication, integrity protection and ciphering are tied together in an EPS security context and identified by a key set identifier for E-UTRAN.
{219, 1} The relationship between the security parameters is defined in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19].
---

{220, 0} Before security can be activated, the MME and the UE need to establish an EPS security context.
---

{220, 0} Before security can be activated, the MME and the UE need to establish an EPS security context.
{220, 1} Usually, the EPS security context is created as the result of an EPS authentication procedure between MME and UE.
---

{220, 0} Before security can be activated, the MME and the UE need to establish an EPS security context.
{220, 1} Usually, the EPS security context is created as the result of an EPS authentication procedure between MME and UE.
{220, 2} Alternatively, during inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or from Iu mode to S1 mode, the MME and the UE derive a mapped EPS security context from a UMTS security context that has been established while the UE was in A/Gb mode or Iu mode;
---

{220, 0} Before security can be activated, the MME and the UE need to establish an EPS security context.
{220, 1} Usually, the EPS security context is created as the result of an EPS authentication procedure between MME and UE.
{220, 2} Alternatively, during CS to PS SRVCC handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or from Iu mode to S1 mode, the MME and the UE derive a mapped EPS security context from a CS UMTS security context that has been established while the UE was in A/Gb mode or Iu mode.
---

{223, 0} The EPS security context is taken into use by the UE and the MME, when the MME initiates a security mode control procedure or during the inter-system handover procedure from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode.
---

{223, 0} The EPS security context is taken into use by the UE and the MME, when the MME initiates a security mode control procedure or during the inter-system handover procedure from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode.
{223, 1} The EPS security context which has been taken into use by the network most recently is called current EPS security context.
---

{223, 0} The EPS security context is taken into use by the UE and the MME, when the MME initiates a security mode control procedure or during the inter-system handover procedure from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode.
{223, 1} The EPS security context which has been taken into use by the network most recently is called current EPS security context.
{223, 2} This current EPS security context can be of type native or mapped, i.e. originating from a native EPS security context or mapped EPS security context.
---

{224, 0} The key set identifier eKSI is assigned by the MME either during the EPS authentication procedure or, for the mapped EPS security context, during the inter-system handover procedure.
---

{224, 0} The key set identifier eKSI is assigned by the MME either during the EPS authentication procedure or, for the mapped EPS security context, during the inter-system handover procedure.
{224, 1} The eKSI consists of a value and a type of security context parameter indicating whether an EPS security context is a native EPS security context or a mapped EPS security context.
---

{224, 0} The key set identifier eKSI is assigned by the MME either during the EPS authentication procedure or, for the mapped EPS security context, during the inter-system handover procedure.
{224, 1} The eKSI consists of a value and a type of security context parameter indicating whether an EPS security context is a native EPS security context or a mapped EPS security context.
{224, 2} When the EPS security context is a native EPS security context, the eKSI has the value of KSIASME, and when the current EPS security context is of type mapped, the eKSI has the value of KSISGSN.
---

{225, 0} The EPS security context which is indicated by an eKSI can be taken into use to establish the secure exchange of NAS messages when a new NAS signalling connection is established without executing a new EPS authentication procedure or when the MME initiates a security mode control procedure.
---

{225, 0} The EPS security context which is indicated by an eKSI can be taken into use to establish the secure exchange of NAS messages when a new NAS signalling connection is established without executing a new EPS authentication procedure or when the MME initiates a security mode control procedure.
{225, 1} For this purpose the initial NAS messages and the SECURITY MODE COMMAND message contain an eKSI in the NAS key set identifier IE or the value part of eKSI in the KSI and sequence number IE indicating the current EPS security context used to integrity protect the NAS message.
---

{226, 0} In the present document, when the UE is required to delete an eKSI, the UE shall set the eKSI to the value "no key is available" and consider also the associated keys KASME or K'ASME, EPS NAS ciphering key and EPS NAS integrity key invalid.
---

{227, 0} The UE and the MME need to be able to maintain two EPS security contexts simultaneously, i.e. a current EPS security context and a non-current EPS security context, since, after an EPS re-authentication, the UE and the MME can have both a current EPS security context and a non-current EPS security context which has not yet been taken into use;
---

{227, 0} The UE and the MME need to be able to maintain two EPS security contexts simultaneously, i.e. a current EPS security context and a non-current EPS security context, since, after an inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the UE and the MME can have both a mapped EPS security context, which is the current EPS security context, and a non-current native EPS security context that was created during a previous access in S1 mode or S101 mode.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{231, 0} After a successful EPS authentication, which creates a new partial native EPS security context, the MME and the UE shall delete the non-current EPS security context, if any.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{232, 0} When a partial native EPS security context is taken into use through a security mode control procedure, the MME and the UE shall delete the previously current EPS security context.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{233, 0} When the MME and the UE create an EPS security context using null integrity and null ciphering algorithm during an attach procedure for emergency bearer services, or a tracking area updating procedure for a UE that has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services, the MME and the UE shall delete the previous current EPS security context.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{234, 0} When a new mapped EPS security context or EPS security context created using null integrity and null ciphering algorithm is taken into use during the inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the MME and the UE shall not delete the previously current native EPS security context, if any.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{234, 0} When a new mapped EPS security context or EPS security context created using null integrity and null ciphering algorithm is taken into use during the inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the MME and the UE shall not delete the previously current native EPS security context, if any.
{234, 1} Instead, the previously current native EPS security context shall become a non-current native EPS security context, and the MME and the UE shall delete any partial native EPS security context.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{234, 0} When a new mapped EPS security context or EPS security context created using null integrity and null ciphering algorithm is taken into use during the inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the MME and the UE shall not delete the previously current native EPS security context, if any.
{234, 1} Instead, the previously current native EPS security context shall become a non-current native EPS security context, and the MME and the UE shall delete any partial native EPS security context.
{235, 0} If no previously current native EPS security context exists, the MME and the UE shall not delete the partial native EPS security context, if any.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{236, 0} When the MME and the UE derive a new mapped EPS security context during inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the MME and the UE shall delete any existing current mapped EPS security context.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{237, 0} When a non-current full native EPS security context is taken into use by a security mode control procedure, then the MME and the UE shall delete the previously current mapped EPS security context.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{238, 0} When the UE or the MME moves from EMM-REGISTERED to EMM-DEREGISTERED state, if the current EPS security context is a mapped EPS security context and a non-current full native EPS security context exists, then the non-current EPS security context shall become the current EPS security context.
---

{230, 0} The number of EPS security contexts that need to be maintained simultaneously by the UE and the MME is limited by the following requirements:
{238, 0} When the UE or the MME moves from EMM-REGISTERED to EMM-DEREGISTERED state, if the current EPS security context is a mapped EPS security context and a non-current full native EPS security context exists, then the non-current EPS security context shall become the current EPS security context.
{238, 1} Furthermore, the UE and the MME shall delete any mapped EPS security context or partial native EPS security context.
---

{239, 0} The UE shall mark the EPS security context on the USIM or in the non-volatile memory as invalid when the UE initiates an attach procedure as described in subclause 5.5.1 or when the UE leaves state EMM-DEREGISTERED for any other state except EMM-NULL.
---

{240, 0} The UE shall store the current native EPS security context as specified in annex C and mark it as valid only when the UE enters state EMM-DEREGISTERED from any other state except EMM-NULL or when the UE aborts the attach procedure without having left EMM-DEREGISTERED.
---

{249, 0} Secure exchange of NAS messages via a NAS signalling connection is usually established by the MME during the attach procedure by initiating a security mode control procedure.
---

{249, 0} Secure exchange of NAS messages via a NAS signalling connection is usually established by the MME during the attach procedure by initiating a security mode control procedure.
{249, 1} After successful completion of the security mode control procedure, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent integrity protected using the current EPS security algorithms, and except for the messages specified in subclause 4.4.5, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent ciphered using the current EPS security algorithms.
---

{250, 0} During inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, secure exchange of NAS messages is established between the MME and the UE by, the transmission of NAS security related parameters encapsulated in the AS signalling from the MME to the UE triggering the inter-system handover.
---

{250, 0} During inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, secure exchange of NAS messages is established between the MME and the UE by, the transmission of NAS security related parameters encapsulated in the AS signalling from the MME to the UE triggering the inter-system handover.
{251, 1} The UE uses these parameters to generate the mapped EPS security context;
---

{250, 0} During inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, secure exchange of NAS messages is established between the MME and the UE by, after the handover, the transmission of a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message from the UE to the MME.
---

{250, 0} During inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, secure exchange of NAS messages is established between the MME and the UE by, after the handover, the transmission of a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message from the UE to the MME.
{252, 1} The UE shall send this message integrity protected using the mapped EPS security context, but unciphered.
---

{250, 0} During inter-system handover from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, secure exchange of NAS messages is established between the MME and the UE by, after the handover, the transmission of a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message from the UE to the MME.
{252, 1} The UE shall send this message integrity protected using the mapped EPS security context, but unciphered.
{252, 2} From this time onward, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent integrity protected using the mapped EPS security context, and except for the messages specified in subclause 4.4.5, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent ciphered using the mapped EPS security context.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the tracking area updating procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], the UE shall transmit a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the tracking area updating procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], the UE shall transmit a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.
{257, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the tracking area updating procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], the UE shall transmit a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.
{257, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
{257, 2} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the 5G NAS security context value in the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the tracking area updating procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], the UE shall transmit a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.
{257, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
{257, 2} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the 5G NAS security context value in the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message.
{258, 0} After receiving the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME forwards the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message to the source AMF, if possible, to obtain the mapped EPS security context from the AMF as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the tracking area updating procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], the UE shall transmit a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.
{257, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
{257, 2} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the 5G NAS security context value in the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message.
{258, 0} After receiving the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME forwards the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message to the source AMF, if possible, to obtain the mapped EPS security context from the AMF as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
{258, 1} The MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the tracking area updating procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], the UE shall transmit a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.
{257, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
{257, 2} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the 5G NAS security context value in the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message.
{258, 0} After receiving the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME forwards the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message to the source AMF, if possible, to obtain the mapped EPS security context from the AMF as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
{258, 1} The MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
{258, 2} The MME re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages by either, replying with a TRACKING AREA UPDATE ACCEPT message that is integrity protected and ciphered using the mapped EPS security context.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the tracking area updating procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], the UE shall transmit a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.

{257, 2} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the 5G NAS security context value in the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message.
{258, 0} After receiving the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME forwards the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message to the source AMF, if possible, to obtain the mapped EPS security context from the AMF as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
{258, 1} The MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
{258, 2} The MME re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages by either, replying with a TRACKING AREA UPDATE ACCEPT message that is integrity protected and ciphered using the mapped EPS security context.
{259, 1} From this time onward, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent integrity protected and except for the messages specified in subclause 4.4.5, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent ciphered;

{262, 2} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the 5G NAS security context value in the ATTACH REQUEST message.
{263, 0} After receiving the ATTACH REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME forwards the ATTACH REQUEST message to the source AMF, if possible, to obtain the mapped EPS security context from the AMF as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
{263, 1} The MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
{263, 2} The MME re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages by either, replying with an ATTACH ACCEPT message that is integrity protected and ciphered using the mapped EPS NAS security context.
{264, 1} From this time onward, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent integrity protected and except for the messages specified in subclause 4.4.5, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent ciphered;
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, if the UE has received an "interworking without N26 interface not supported" indication from the network and the UE has a valid 5G NAS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.
{262, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
{262, 2} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the 5G NAS security context value in the ATTACH REQUEST message.
{263, 0} After receiving the ATTACH REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME forwards the ATTACH REQUEST message to the source AMF, if possible, to obtain the mapped EPS security context from the AMF as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
{263, 1} The MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
{263, 2} The MME re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages by either, initiating a security mode control procedure.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, if the UE has received an "interworking without N26 interface not supported" indication from the network and the UE has a valid 5G NAS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the current 5G NAS security context and the UE shall derive a mapped EPS security context.
{262, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
{262, 2} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the 5G NAS security context value in the ATTACH REQUEST message.
{263, 0} After receiving the ATTACH REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME forwards the ATTACH REQUEST message to the source AMF, if possible, to obtain the mapped EPS security context from the AMF as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56].
{263, 1} The MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
{263, 2} The MME re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages by either, initiating a security mode control procedure.
{265, 1} This can be used by the MME to modify the current EPS security context by selecting new NAS security algorithms;
