{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, otherwise, if the UE has a valid native EPS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the native EPS security context.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, otherwise, if the UE has a valid native EPS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the native EPS security context.
{267, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the native EPS security context value in the ATTACH REQUEST message.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, otherwise, if the UE has a valid native EPS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the native EPS security context.
{267, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the native EPS security context value in the ATTACH REQUEST message.
{268, 0} After receiving the ATTACH REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, otherwise, if the UE has a valid native EPS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the native EPS security context.
{267, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the native EPS security context value in the ATTACH REQUEST message.
{268, 0} After receiving the ATTACH REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
{268, 1} If the verification is successful, the MME re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages by either, replying with an ATTACH ACCEPT message that is integrity protected and ciphered using the current EPS security context.
---

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, otherwise, if the UE has a valid native EPS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the native EPS security context.
{267, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the native EPS security context value in the ATTACH REQUEST message.
{268, 0} After receiving the ATTACH REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
{268, 1} If the verification is successful, the MME re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages by either, replying with an ATTACH ACCEPT message that is integrity protected and ciphered using the current EPS security context.
{269, 1} From this time onward, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent integrity protected and except for the messages specified in subclause 4.4.5, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent ciphered;

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, otherwise, if the UE has a valid native EPS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the native EPS security context.
{267, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the native EPS security context value in the ATTACH REQUEST message.
{268, 0} After receiving the ATTACH REQUEST message including the eKSI, the MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
{268, 1} If the verification is successful, the MME re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages by either, initiating a security mode control procedure.

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, otherwise, if the UE has a valid native EPS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message integrity protected with the native EPS security context.

{256, 0} During inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode, if the UE is operating in the single-registration mode and, if the attach procedure is initiated as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] and, otherwise, if the UE has no valid native EPS security context, the UE shall send an ATTACH REQUEST message without integrity protection and encryption.

{272, 0} The secure exchange of NAS messages shall be continued after S1 mode to S1 mode handover.
---

{272, 0} The secure exchange of NAS messages shall be continued after S1 mode to S1 mode handover.
{272, 1} It is terminated after inter-system handover from S1 mode to A/Gb mode or Iu mode or when the NAS signalling connection is released.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{274, 0} Except for the cases described in items 3 and 4 below, the UE shall transmit the initial NAS message integrity protected with the current EPS security context, but unciphered.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{274, 0} Except for the cases described in items 3 and 4 below, the UE shall transmit the initial NAS message integrity protected with the current EPS security context, but unciphered.
{274, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the current EPS security context value in the initial NAS message.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{274, 0} Except for the cases described in items 3 and 4 below, the UE shall transmit the initial NAS message integrity protected with the current EPS security context, but unciphered.
{274, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the current EPS security context value in the initial NAS message.
{274, 2} The MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{274, 0} Except for the cases described in items 3 and 4 below, the UE shall transmit the initial NAS message integrity protected with the current EPS security context, but unciphered.
{274, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the current EPS security context value in the initial NAS message.
{274, 2} The MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
{274, 3} If the verification is successful, the MME may re-establish the secure exchange of NAS messages, by replying with a NAS message that is integrity protected and ciphered using the current EPS security context.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{274, 0} Except for the cases described in items 3 and 4 below, the UE shall transmit the initial NAS message integrity protected with the current EPS security context, but unciphered.
{274, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the current EPS security context value in the initial NAS message.
{274, 2} The MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
{274, 3} If the verification is successful, the MME may re-establish the secure exchange of NAS messages, by replying with a NAS message that is integrity protected and ciphered using the current EPS security context.
{275, 1} From this time onward, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent integrity protected and except for the messages specified in subclause 4.4.5, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent ciphered;
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{274, 0} Except for the cases described in items 3 and 4 below, the UE shall transmit the initial NAS message integrity protected with the current EPS security context, but unciphered.
{274, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the current EPS security context value in the initial NAS message.
{274, 2} The MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
{274, 3} If the verification is successful, the MME may re-establish the secure exchange of NAS messages, by initiating a security mode control procedure.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{274, 0} Except for the cases described in items 3 and 4 below, the UE shall transmit the initial NAS message integrity protected with the current EPS security context, but unciphered.
{274, 1} The UE shall include the eKSI indicating the current EPS security context value in the initial NAS message.
{274, 2} The MME shall check whether the eKSI included in the initial NAS message belongs to an EPS security context available in the MME, and shall verify the MAC of the NAS message.
{274, 3} If the verification is successful, the MME may re-establish the secure exchange of NAS messages, by initiating a security mode control procedure.
{276, 1} This can be used by the MME to take a non-current EPS security context into use or to modify the current EPS security context by selecting new NAS security algorithms;
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{277, 0} If the initial NAS message was a SERVICE REQUEST message or EXTENDED SERVICE REQUEST message, secure exchange of NAS messages is triggered by the indication from the lower layers that the user plane radio bearers are successfully set up.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{277, 0} If the initial NAS message was a SERVICE REQUEST message or EXTENDED SERVICE REQUEST message, secure exchange of NAS messages is triggered by the indication from the lower layers that the user plane radio bearers are successfully set up.
{277, 1} After successful completion of the procedure, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent integrity protected and except for the messages specified in subclause 4.4.5, all NAS messages exchanged between the UE and the MME are sent ciphered.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{278, 0} If the UE has no current EPS security context and performs a tracking area updating procedure after an inter-system change in idle mode from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the UE shall send the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message without integrity protection and encryption.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{278, 0} If the UE has no current EPS security context and performs a tracking area updating procedure after an inter-system change in idle mode from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the UE shall send the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message without integrity protection and encryption.
{278, 1} The UE shall include a nonce and a GPRS ciphering key sequence number for creation of a mapped EPS security context.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{278, 0} If the UE has no current EPS security context and performs a tracking area updating procedure after an inter-system change in idle mode from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the UE shall send the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message without integrity protection and encryption.
{278, 1} The UE shall include a nonce and a GPRS ciphering key sequence number for creation of a mapped EPS security context.
{278, 2} The MME creates a fresh mapped EPS security context and takes this context into use by initiating a security mode control procedure and this context becomes the current EPS security context in both the UE and the MME.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{278, 0} If the UE has no current EPS security context and performs a tracking area updating procedure after an inter-system change in idle mode from A/Gb mode to S1 mode or Iu mode to S1 mode, the UE shall send the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message without integrity protection and encryption.
{278, 1} The UE shall include a nonce and a GPRS ciphering key sequence number for creation of a mapped EPS security context.
{278, 2} The MME creates a fresh mapped EPS security context and takes this context into use by initiating a security mode control procedure and this context becomes the current EPS security context in both the UE and the MME.
{278, 3} This re-establishes the secure exchange of NAS messages.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{279, 0} If the initial NAS message is a CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message, the UE shall send the message integrity protected.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{279, 0} If the initial NAS message is a CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message, the UE shall send the message integrity protected.
{279, 1} If an ESM message container information element or a NAS message container information element is included the message shall be sent partially ciphered, otherwise the message shall be sent unciphered.
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{279, 0} If the initial NAS message is a CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message, the UE shall send the message integrity protected.
{279, 1} If an ESM message container information element or a NAS message container information element is included the message shall be sent partially ciphered, otherwise the message shall be sent unciphered.
{279, 2} Secure exchange of NAS messages is re-established in the UE, by the indication from the lower layers that the user plane radio bearers are successfully set up;
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{279, 0} If the initial NAS message is a CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message, the UE shall send the message integrity protected.
{279, 1} If an ESM message container information element or a NAS message container information element is included the message shall be sent partially ciphered, otherwise the message shall be sent unciphered.
{279, 2} Secure exchange of NAS messages is re-established in the UE, upon receipt of a NAS message that is integrity protected and ciphered using the current EPS security context;
---

{273, 0} When a UE in EMM-IDLE mode establishes a new NAS signalling connection and has a valid current EPS security context, secure exchange of NAS messages can be re-established in the following ways:
{279, 0} If the initial NAS message is a CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message, the UE shall send the message integrity protected.
{279, 1} If an ESM message container information element or a NAS message container information element is included the message shall be sent partially ciphered, otherwise the message shall be sent unciphered.
{279, 2} Secure exchange of NAS messages is re-established in the UE, upon receipt of a SECURITY MODE COMMAND message that has successfully passed the integrity check.
---

{284, 0} When the MME initiates a re-authentication to create a new EPS security context, the messages exchanged during the authentication procedure are integrity protected and ciphered using the current EPS security context, if any.
---

{285, 0} Both UE and MME shall continue to use the current EPS security context, until the MME initiates a security mode control procedure.
---

{285, 0} Both UE and MME shall continue to use the current EPS security context, until the MME initiates a security mode control procedure.
{285, 1} The SECURITY MODE COMMAND message sent by the MME includes the eKSI of the new EPS security context to be used.
---

{285, 0} Both UE and MME shall continue to use the current EPS security context, until the MME initiates a security mode control procedure.
{285, 1} The SECURITY MODE COMMAND message sent by the MME includes the eKSI of the new EPS security context to be used.
{285, 2} The MME shall send the SECURITY MODE COMMAND message integrity protected with the new EPS security context, but unciphered.
---

{285, 0} Both UE and MME shall continue to use the current EPS security context, until the MME initiates a security mode control procedure.
{285, 1} The SECURITY MODE COMMAND message sent by the MME includes the eKSI of the new EPS security context to be used.
{285, 2} The MME shall send the SECURITY MODE COMMAND message integrity protected with the new EPS security context, but unciphered.
{285, 3} When the UE responds with a SECURITY MODE COMPLETE, it shall send the message integrity protected and ciphered with the new EPS security context.
---

{286, 0} The MME can also modify the current EPS security context or take the non-current native EPS security context, if any, into use, by sending a SECURITY MODE COMMAND message including the eKSI of the EPS security context to be modified and including a new set of selected NAS security algorithms.
---

{286, 0} The MME can also modify the current EPS security context or take the non-current native EPS security context, if any, into use, by sending a SECURITY MODE COMMAND message including the eKSI of the EPS security context to be modified and including a new set of selected NAS security algorithms.
{286, 1} In this case the MME shall send the SECURITY MODE COMMAND message integrity protected with the modified EPS security context, but unciphered.
---

{286, 0} The MME can also modify the current EPS security context or take the non-current native EPS security context, if any, into use, by sending a SECURITY MODE COMMAND message including the eKSI of the EPS security context to be modified and including a new set of selected NAS security algorithms.
{286, 1} In this case the MME shall send the SECURITY MODE COMMAND message integrity protected with the modified EPS security context, but unciphered.
{286, 2} When the UE replies with a SECURITY MODE COMPLETE message, it shall send the message integrity protected and ciphered with the modified EPS security context.
---

{298, 0} Each EPS security context shall be associated with two separate counters NAS COUNT: one related to uplink NAS messages and one related to downlink NAS messages.
---

{298, 0} Each EPS security context shall be associated with two separate counters NAS COUNT: one related to uplink NAS messages and one related to downlink NAS messages.
{298, 1} The NAS COUNT counters use 24 bit internal representation and are independently maintained by UE and MME.
---

{298, 0} Each EPS security context shall be associated with two separate counters NAS COUNT: one related to uplink NAS messages and one related to downlink NAS messages.
{298, 1} The NAS COUNT counters use 24 bit internal representation and are independently maintained by UE and MME.
{298, 2} The NAS COUNT shall be constructed as a NAS sequence number concatenated with a NAS overflow counter.
---

{299, 0} When NAS COUNT is input to NAS ciphering or NAS integrity algorithms it shall be considered to be a 32-bit entity which shall be constructed by padding the 24-bit internal representation with 8 zeros in the most significant bits.
---

{300, 0} The value of the uplink NAS COUNT that is stored or read out of the USIM or non-volatile memory as described in annex C, is the value that shall be used in the next NAS message.
---

{301, 0} The value of the downlink NAS COUNT that is stored or read out of the USIM or non-volatile memory as described in annex C, is the largest downlink NAS COUNT used in a successfully integrity checked NAS message.
---

{302, 0} The NAS sequence number part of the NAS COUNT shall be exchanged between the UE and the MME as part of the NAS signalling.
---

{302, 0} The NAS sequence number part of the NAS COUNT shall be exchanged between the UE and the MME as part of the NAS signalling.
{302, 1} After each new or retransmitted outbound security protected NAS message, the sender shall increase the NAS COUNT number by one, except for the initial NAS messages if the lower layers indicated the failure to establish the RRC connection.
---

{302, 0} The NAS sequence number part of the NAS COUNT shall be exchanged between the UE and the MME as part of the NAS signalling.
{302, 1} After each new or retransmitted outbound security protected NAS message, the sender shall increase the NAS COUNT number by one, except for the initial NAS messages if the lower layers indicated the failure to establish the RRC connection.
{302, 2} Specifically, on the sender side, the NAS sequence number shall be increased by one, and if the result is zero, the NAS overflow counter shall also be incremented by one.
---

{302, 0} The NAS sequence number part of the NAS COUNT shall be exchanged between the UE and the MME as part of the NAS signalling.
{302, 1} After each new or retransmitted outbound security protected NAS message, the sender shall increase the NAS COUNT number by one, except for the initial NAS messages if the lower layers indicated the failure to establish the RRC connection.
{302, 2} Specifically, on the sender side, the NAS sequence number shall be increased by one, and if the result is zero, the NAS overflow counter shall also be incremented by one.
{302, 3} The receiving side shall estimate the NAS COUNT used by the sending side.
---

{302, 0} The NAS sequence number part of the NAS COUNT shall be exchanged between the UE and the MME as part of the NAS signalling.
{302, 1} After each new or retransmitted outbound security protected NAS message, the sender shall increase the NAS COUNT number by one, except for the initial NAS messages if the lower layers indicated the failure to establish the RRC connection.
{302, 2} Specifically, on the sender side, the NAS sequence number shall be increased by one, and if the result is zero, the NAS overflow counter shall also be incremented by one.
{302, 3} The receiving side shall estimate the NAS COUNT used by the sending side.
{302, 4} Specifically, if the estimated NAS sequence number wraps around, the NAS overflow counter shall be incremented by one.
---

{303, 0} After the derivation of a NAS token due to an inter-system change from S1mode to A/Gb mode or Iu mode in idle mode as specified in 3GPP TS 24.008 [13], the UE shall increase the uplink NAS COUNT by one.
---

{304, 0} When the MME receives a NAS token via SGSN during an idle mode inter-system change from S1 mode to A/Gb mode or Iu mode, the MME shall check the NAS token as specified in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19], subclause 9.1.1, and update its uplink NAS COUNT with the uplink NAS COUNT value used for the successful check of the NAS token.
---

{305, 0} During the handover from UTRAN/GERAN to E-UTRAN, when a mapped EPS security context is derived and taken into use, the MME shall set both the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of this EPS security context to zero.
---

{305, 0} During the handover from UTRAN/GERAN to E-UTRAN, when a mapped EPS security context is derived and taken into use, the MME shall set both the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of this EPS security context to zero.
{305, 1} The UE shall set both the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to zero.
---

{306, 0} When a mapped EPS security context is derived as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56] and taken into use during the inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in 5GMM-CONNECTED mode, the MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
---

{306, 0} When a mapped EPS security context is derived as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56] and taken into use during the inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in 5GMM-CONNECTED mode, the MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
{306, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
---

{307, 0} When a mapped EPS security context is derived as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56] and taken into use during the inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode for the UE operating in single-registration mode in a network supporting N26 interface, the MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
---

{307, 0} When a mapped EPS security context is derived as specified in 3GPP TS 33.501 [56] and taken into use during the inter-system change from N1 mode to S1 mode in EMM-IDLE mode for the UE operating in single-registration mode in a network supporting N26 interface, the MME shall store the mapped EPS NAS security context with the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters associated with the derived K'ASME key set to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the mapped EPS NAS security context respectively.
{307, 1} The UE shall set the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters to the uplink and downlink NAS COUNT counters of the current 5G NAS security context respectively.
---

{308, 0} During the handover from E-UTRAN to UTRAN/GERAN the MME signals the current downlink NAS COUNT value in a NAS security transparent container.
---

{309, 0} During handover to or from E-UTRAN, the MME shall increment downlink NAS COUNT by one after it has created a NAS security transparent container.
---

{310, 0} In some NAS messages only 5 of the 8 NAS sequence number bits are transmitted.
---

{310, 0} In some NAS messages only 5 of the 8 NAS sequence number bits are transmitted.
{310, 1} When this is the case, the receiver shall estimate the remaining 3 most significant bits of the sequence number.
---

{312, 0} Replay protection shall be supported for received NAS messages both in the MME and the UE.
---

{312, 0} Replay protection shall be supported for received NAS messages both in the MME and the UE.
{312, 1} However, since the realization of replay protection does not affect the interoperability between nodes, no specific mechanism is required for implementation.
---

{313, 0} Replay protection must assure that one and the same NAS message is not accepted twice by the receiver.
---

{313, 0} Replay protection must assure that one and the same NAS message is not accepted twice by the receiver.
{313, 1} Specifically, for a given EPS security context, a given NAS COUNT value shall be accepted at most one time and only if message integrity verifies correctly.
---

{314, 0} Replay protection is not applicable when EIA0 is used.
---

{316, 0} The sender shall use its locally stored NAS COUNT as input to the integrity protection algorithm.
---

{317, 0} The receiver shall use the NAS sequence number included in the received message and an estimate for the NAS overflow counter as defined in subclause 4.4.3.1 to form the NAS COUNT input to the integrity verification algorithm.
---

{318, 0} The algorithm to calculate the integrity protection information is specified in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19], and the integrity protection shall include octet 6 to n of the security protected NAS message, i.e. the sequence number IE and the NAS message IE.
---

{318, 0} The algorithm to calculate the integrity protection information is specified in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19], and the integrity protection shall include octet 6 to n of the security protected NAS message, i.e. the sequence number IE and the NAS message IE.
{318, 1} The integrity protection of the SERVICE REQUEST message is defined in subclause 9.9.3.28.
---

{318, 0} The algorithm to calculate the integrity protection information is specified in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19], and the integrity protection shall include octet 6 to n of the security protected NAS message, i.e. the sequence number IE and the NAS message IE.
{318, 1} The integrity protection of the SERVICE REQUEST message is defined in subclause 9.9.3.28.
{318, 2} In addition to the data that is to be integrity protected, the constant BEARER ID, DIRECTION bit, NAS COUNT and NAS integrity key are input to the integrity protection algorithm.
---

{318, 0} The algorithm to calculate the integrity protection information is specified in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19], and the integrity protection shall include octet 6 to n of the security protected NAS message, i.e. the sequence number IE and the NAS message IE.
{318, 1} The integrity protection of the SERVICE REQUEST message is defined in subclause 9.9.3.28.
{318, 2} In addition to the data that is to be integrity protected, the constant BEARER ID, DIRECTION bit, NAS COUNT and NAS integrity key are input to the integrity protection algorithm.
{318, 3} These parameters are described in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19].
---

{319, 0} After successful integrity protection validation, the receiver shall update its corresponding locally stored NAS COUNT with the value of the estimated NAS COUNT for this NAS message.
---

{320, 0} Integrity verification is not applicable when EIA0 is used.
---

{322, 0} The sender shall use its locally stored NAS COUNT as input to the ciphering algorithm.
---

{323, 0} The receiver shall use the NAS sequence number included in the received message and an estimate for the NAS overflow counter as defined in subclause 4.4.3.1 to form the NAS COUNT input to the deciphering algorithm.
---

{324, 0} The input parameters to the NAS ciphering algorithm are the constant BEARER ID, DIRECTION bit, NAS COUNT, NAS encryption key and the length of the key stream to be generated by the encryption algorithm.
---

{324, 0} The input parameters to the NAS ciphering algorithm are the constant BEARER ID, DIRECTION bit, NAS COUNT, NAS encryption key and the length of the key stream to be generated by the encryption algorithm.
{324, 1} When an initial plain NAS message for transport of user data via control plane is to be partially ciphered, the length of the key stream is set to the length of the part of the initial plain NAS message that is to be ciphered.
---

{326, 0} If, when increasing the NAS COUNT as specified above, the MME detects that either its downlink NAS COUNT or the UE's uplink NAS COUNT is "close" to wrap around,, the MME shall take the following actions:
{327, 0} If there is no non-current native EPS security context with sufficiently low NAS COUNT values, the MME shall initiate a new AKA procedure with the UE, leading to a new established EPS security context and the NAS COUNT being reset to 0 in both the UE and the MME when the new EPS security context is activated;
---

{326, 0} If, when increasing the NAS COUNT as specified above, the MME detects that either its downlink NAS COUNT or the UE's uplink NAS COUNT is "close" to wrap around,, the MME shall take the following actions:
{328, 0} Otherwise, the MME can activate a non-current native EPS security context with sufficiently low NAS COUNT values or initiate a new AKA procedure as specified above.
---

{329, 0} If for some reason a new KASME has not been established using AKA before the NAS COUNT wraps around, the node in need of sending a NAS message shall instead release the NAS signalling connection.
---

{329, 0} If for some reason a new KASME has not been established using AKA before the NAS COUNT wraps around, the node in need of sending a NAS message shall instead release the NAS signalling connection.
{329, 1} Prior to sending the next uplink NAS message, the UE shall delete the eKSI indicating the current EPS security context.

---

{330, 1} If NAS COUNT wrap around occurs, the following requirements apply:
{331, 0} the UE and the MME shall continue to use the current security context;
---

{330, 0} When the EIA0 is used as the NAS integrity algorithm, the UE and the MME shall allow NAS COUNT wrap around.
{330, 1} If NAS COUNT wrap around occurs, the following requirements apply:
{332, 0} the MME shall not initiate the EPS AKA procedure;
---

{330, 0} When the EIA0 is used as the NAS integrity algorithm, the UE and the MME shall allow NAS COUNT wrap around.
{330, 1} If NAS COUNT wrap around occurs, the following requirements apply:
{333, 0} the MME shall not release the NAS signalling connection;

{330, 0} When the EIA0 is used as the NAS integrity algorithm, the UE and the MME shall allow NAS COUNT wrap around.

{334, 0} the UE shall not perform a local release of the NAS signalling connection.

{337, 0} For the UE, integrity protected signalling is mandatory for the NAS messages once a valid EPS security context exists and has been taken into use.

{337, 1} For the network, integrity protected signalling is mandatory for the NAS messages once a secure exchange of NAS messages has been established for the NAS signalling connection.

{337, 1} For the network, integrity protected signalling is mandatory for the NAS messages once a secure exchange of NAS messages has been established for the NAS signalling connection.
{337, 2} Integrity protection of all NAS signalling messages is the responsibility of the NAS.

{337, 0} For the UE, integrity protected signalling is mandatory for the NAS messages once a valid EPS security context exists and has been taken into use.
{337, 1} For the network, integrity protected signalling is mandatory for the NAS messages once a secure exchange of NAS messages has been established for the NAS signalling connection.
{337, 2} Integrity protection of all NAS signalling messages is the responsibility of the NAS.
{337, 3} It is the network which activates integrity protection.

{338, 0} The use of "null integrity protection algorithm" EIA0 in the current security context is only allowed for an unauthenticated UE for which establishment of emergency bearer services or access to RLOS is allowed.

{338, 1} For setting the security header type in outbound NAS messages, the UE and the MME shall apply the same rules irrespective of whether the "null integrity protection algorithm" or any other integrity protection algorithm is indicated in the security context.

{339, 0} If the "null integrity protection algorithm" EIA0 has been selected as a integrity protection algorithm, the receiver shall regard the NAS messages with the security header indicating integrity protection as integrity protected.

{340, 0} Details of the integrity protection and verification of NAS signalling messages are specified in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19].

{341, 0} When a NAS message needs to be sent both ciphered and integrity protected, the NAS message is first ciphered and then the ciphered NAS message and the NAS sequence number are integrity protected by calculating the MAC.

{341, 0} When a NAS message needs to be sent both ciphered and integrity protected, the NAS message is first ciphered and then the ciphered NAS message and the NAS sequence number are integrity protected by calculating the MAC.
{341, 1} The same applies when an initial NAS message needs to be sent partially ciphered and integrity protected.
---

{342, 0} When a NAS message needs to be sent only integrity protected and unciphered, the unciphered NAS message and the NAS sequence number are integrity protected by calculating the MAC.

{355, 0} Once the secure exchange of NAS messages has been established, the receiving EMM or ESM entity in the UE shall not process any NAS signalling messages unless they have been successfully integrity checked by the NAS.

{355, 3} If any NAS signalling message is received as not integrity protected even though the secure exchange of NAS messages has been established by the network, then the NAS shall discard this message.

{380, 0} If an ATTACH REQUEST message is received without integrity protection or fails the integrity check and it is not an attach request for emergency bearer services and it is not an attach request for access to RLOS, the MME shall authenticate the subscriber before processing the attach request any further.

{381, 0} If a DETACH REQUEST message fails the integrity check, the MME shall proceed as follows:
{382, 0} If it is not a detach request due to switch off, and the MME can initiate an authentication procedure, the MME should authenticate the subscriber before processing the detach request any further.
---

{384, 0} If a TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message is received without integrity protection or fails the integrity check and the UE provided a nonceUE, GPRS ciphering key sequence number, P-TMSI and RAI in the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message, the MME shall initiate a security mode control procedure to take a new mapped EPS security context into use; otherwise, if the UE has only a PDN connection for non-emergency bearer services established and the PDN connection is not for RLOS, the MME shall initiate an authentication procedure.
---

{385, 0} If a SERVICE REQUEST, EXTENDED SERVICE REQUEST or CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message fails the integrity check and the UE has only PDN connections for non-emergency bearer services established and the PDN connections are not for RLOS, the MME shall send the SERVICE REJECT message with EMM cause #9 "UE identity cannot be derived by the network" and keep the EMM-context and EPS security context unchanged.
---

{385, 0} If a SERVICE REQUEST, EXTENDED SERVICE REQUEST or CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message fails the integrity check and the UE has only PDN connections for non-emergency bearer services established and the PDN connections are not for RLOS, the MME shall send the SERVICE REJECT message with EMM cause #9 "UE identity cannot be derived by the network" and keep the EMM-context and EPS security context unchanged.
{385, 1} For the case when the UE has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services or RLOS and integrity check fails, the MME may skip the authentication procedure even if no EPS security context is available and proceed directly to the execution of the security mode control procedure as specified in subclause 5.4.3.
---

{385, 0} If a SERVICE REQUEST, EXTENDED SERVICE REQUEST or CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message fails the integrity check and the UE has only PDN connections for non-emergency bearer services established and the PDN connections are not for RLOS, the MME shall send the SERVICE REJECT message with EMM cause #9 "UE identity cannot be derived by the network" and keep the EMM-context and EPS security context unchanged.
{385, 1} For the case when the UE has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services or RLOS and integrity check fails, the MME may skip the authentication procedure even if no EPS security context is available and proceed directly to the execution of the security mode control procedure as specified in subclause 5.4.3.
{385, 2} After successful completion of the service request procedure, the network shall deactivate all non-emergency EPS bearers locally which are not EPS bearers for RLOS.
---

{385, 0} If a SERVICE REQUEST, EXTENDED SERVICE REQUEST or CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message fails the integrity check and the UE has only PDN connections for non-emergency bearer services established and the PDN connections are not for RLOS, the MME shall send the SERVICE REJECT message with EMM cause #9 "UE identity cannot be derived by the network" and keep the EMM-context and EPS security context unchanged.
{385, 1} For the case when the UE has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services or RLOS and integrity check fails, the MME may skip the authentication procedure even if no EPS security context is available and proceed directly to the execution of the security mode control procedure as specified in subclause 5.4.3.
{385, 2} After successful completion of the service request procedure, the network shall deactivate all non-emergency EPS bearers locally which are not EPS bearers for RLOS.
{385, 3} The emergency EPS bearers shall not be deactivated.
---

{385, 0} If a SERVICE REQUEST, EXTENDED SERVICE REQUEST or CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message fails the integrity check and the UE has only PDN connections for non-emergency bearer services established and the PDN connections are not for RLOS, the MME shall send the SERVICE REJECT message with EMM cause #9 "UE identity cannot be derived by the network" and keep the EMM-context and EPS security context unchanged.
{385, 1} For the case when the UE has a PDN connection for emergency bearer services or RLOS and integrity check fails, the MME may skip the authentication procedure even if no EPS security context is available and proceed directly to the execution of the security mode control procedure as specified in subclause 5.4.3.
{385, 2} After successful completion of the service request procedure, the network shall deactivate all non-emergency EPS bearers locally which are not EPS bearers for RLOS.
{385, 3} The emergency EPS bearers shall not be deactivated.
{385, 4} The network may deactivate the EPS bearers for RLOS.
---

{386, 0} Once the secure exchange of NAS messages has been established for the NAS signalling connection, the receiving EMM or ESM entity in the MME shall not process any NAS signalling messages unless they have been successfully integrity checked by the NAS.
---

{386, 0} Once the secure exchange of NAS messages has been established for the NAS signalling connection, the receiving EMM or ESM entity in the MME shall not process any NAS signalling messages unless they have been successfully integrity checked by the NAS.
{386, 1} If any NAS signalling message, having not successfully passed the integrity check, is received, then the NAS in the MME shall discard that message.
---

{386, 0} Once the secure exchange of NAS messages has been established for the NAS signalling connection, the receiving EMM or ESM entity in the MME shall not process any NAS signalling messages unless they have been successfully integrity checked by the NAS.
{386, 1} If any NAS signalling message, having not successfully passed the integrity check, is received, then the NAS in the MME shall discard that message.
{386, 2} If any NAS signalling message is received, as not integrity protected even though the secure exchange of NAS messages has been established, then the NAS shall discard this message.
---

{388, 0} The use of ciphering in a network is an operator option subject to MME configuration.
---

{388, 0} The use of ciphering in a network is an operator option subject to MME configuration.
{388, 1} When operation of the network without ciphering is configured, the MME shall indicate the use of "null ciphering algorithm" EEA0 in the current security context for all UEs.
---

{388, 0} The use of ciphering in a network is an operator option subject to MME configuration.
{388, 1} When operation of the network without ciphering is configured, the MME shall indicate the use of "null ciphering algorithm" EEA0 in the current security context for all UEs.
{388, 2} For setting the security header type in outbound NAS messages, the UE and the MME shall apply the same rules irrespective of whether the "null ciphering algorithm" or any other ciphering algorithm is indicated in the security context.
---

{389, 0} When the UE establishes a new NAS signalling connection, it shall send the initial NAS message partially ciphered, if it is a CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message including an ESM message container information element or a NAS message container information element;
---

{389, 0} When the UE establishes a new NAS signalling connection, it shall send the initial NAS message unciphered, if it is any other initial NAS message.
---

{392, 0} The UE shall partially cipher the CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message by ciphering the value part of the ESM message container IE or the value part of the NAS message container, using the ciphering algorithm of the current EPS security context.
---

{393, 0} The UE shall send the ATTACH REQUEST message always unciphered.
---

{394, 0} The UE shall send the TRACKING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message always unciphered.
---

{395, 0} Except for the CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message including an ESM message container information element or a NAS message container information element, the UE shall start the ciphering and deciphering of NAS messages when the secure exchange of NAS messages has been established for a NAS signalling connection.
---

{395, 0} Except for the CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message including an ESM message container information element or a NAS message container information element, the UE shall start the ciphering and deciphering of NAS messages when the secure exchange of NAS messages has been established for a NAS signalling connection.
{395, 1} From this time onward, unless explicitly defined, the UE shall send all NAS messages ciphered until the NAS signalling connection is released, or the UE performs intersystem handover to A/Gb mode or Iu mode.
---

{396, 0} The MME shall start ciphering and deciphering of NAS messages as described in subclause 4.4.2.3.
---

{396, 0} The MME shall start ciphering and deciphering of NAS messages as described in subclause 4.4.2.3.
{396, 1} From this time onward, except for the SECURITY MODE COMMAND message, the MME shall send all NAS messages ciphered until the NAS signalling connection is released, or the UE performs intersystem handover to A/Gb mode or Iu mode.
---

{397, 0} Once the encryption of NAS messages has been started between the MME and the UE, the receiver shall discard the unciphered NAS messages which shall have been ciphered according to the rules described in this specification.
---

{397, 0} Once the encryption of NAS messages has been started between the MME and the UE, the receiver shall discard the unciphered NAS messages which shall have been ciphered according to the rules described in this specification.
{397, 1} The MME shall discard any CONTROL PLANE SERVICE REQUEST message including an ESM message container information element or a NAS message container information element which has not been partially ciphered according to the rules described above.
---

{398, 0} If the "null ciphering algorithm" EEA0 has been selected as a ciphering algorithm, the NAS messages with the security header indicating ciphering are regarded as ciphered.
---

{399, 0} Details of ciphering and deciphering of NAS signalling messages are specified in 3GPP TS 33.401 [19].
---

{401, 0} The UE shall only disable the E-UTRA capability when in EMM-IDLE mode.
---

{402, 0} When the UE supports both N1 mode and S1 mode then the UE's capability to access the 5GCN via E-UTRA shall not be affected, if the UE's E-UTRA capability is disabled or enabled.
---

{403, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability not due to redirection to 5GCN required, it should proceed as follows:
{404, 0} select another RAT of the registered PLMN or a PLMN from the list of equivalent PLMNs;
---

{403, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability not due to redirection to 5GCN required, it should proceed as follows:
{405, 0} if another RAT of the registered PLMN or a PLMN from the list of equivalent PLMNs cannot be found, or the UE does not have a registered PLMN, then perform PLMN selection as specified in 3GPP TS 23.122 [6].
---

{403, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability not due to redirection to 5GCN required, it should proceed as follows:
{405, 0} if another RAT of the registered PLMN or a PLMN from the list of equivalent PLMNs cannot be found, or the UE does not have a registered PLMN, then perform PLMN selection as specified in 3GPP TS 23.122 [6].
{405, 1} As an implementation option, instead of performing PLMN selection, the UE may select another RAT of the chosen PLMN.
---

{403, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability not due to redirection to 5GCN required, it should proceed as follows:
{405, 0} if another RAT of the registered PLMN or a PLMN from the list of equivalent PLMNs cannot be found, or the UE does not have a registered PLMN, then perform PLMN selection as specified in 3GPP TS 23.122 [6].
{405, 1} As an implementation option, instead of performing PLMN selection, the UE may select another RAT of the chosen PLMN.
{405, 2} If disabling of E-UTRA capability was not due to UE initiated detach procedure for EPS services only, the UE may re-enable the E-UTRA capability for this PLMN selection;
---

{403, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability not due to redirection to 5GCN required, it should proceed as follows:
{406, 0} if no other allowed PLMN and RAT combinations are available, then the UE may re-enable the E-UTRA capability and remain registered for EPS services in E-UTRAN of the registered PLMN.
---

{403, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability not due to redirection to 5GCN required, it should proceed as follows:
{406, 0} if no other allowed PLMN and RAT combinations are available, then the UE may re-enable the E-UTRA capability and remain registered for EPS services in E-UTRAN of the registered PLMN.
{406, 1} If the UE chooses this option, then it may periodically attempt to select another PLMN and RAT combination that can provide non-EPS services.
---

{403, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability not due to redirection to 5GCN required, it should proceed as follows:
{406, 0} if no other allowed PLMN and RAT combinations are available, then the UE may re-enable the E-UTRA capability and remain registered for EPS services in E-UTRAN of the registered PLMN.
{406, 1} If the UE chooses this option, then it may periodically attempt to select another PLMN and RAT combination that can provide non-EPS services.
{406, 2} How this periodic scanning is done, is UE implementation dependent.
---

{407, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability upon receiving reject cause #31 "Redirection to 5GCN required" as specified in subclauses 5.5.1.2.5, 5.5.1.3.5, 5.5.3.2.5, 5.5.3.3.5 and 5.6.1.5, it should proceed as follows:
{408, 0} If the UE is in NB-S1 mode, if lower layers do not provide an indication that the current E-UTRA cell is connected to 5GCN or lower layers do not provide an indication that the current E-UTRA cell supports CIoT 5GS optimizations that are supported by the UE, search for a suitable NB-IoT cell connected to 5GCN according to 3GPP TS 36.304 [21];
---

{407, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability upon receiving reject cause #31 "Redirection to 5GCN required" as specified in subclauses 5.5.1.2.5, 5.5.1.3.5, 5.5.3.2.5, 5.5.3.3.5 and 5.6.1.5, it should proceed as follows:
{408, 0} If the UE is in NB-S1 mode, if lower layers provide an indication that the current E-UTRA cell is connected to 5GCN and the current E-UTRA cell supports CIoT 5GS optimizations that are supported by the UE then perform a core network selection to select 5GCN as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] subclause 4.8.4A.1;
---

{407, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability upon receiving reject cause #31 "Redirection to 5GCN required" as specified in subclauses 5.5.1.2.5, 5.5.1.3.5, 5.5.3.2.5, 5.5.3.3.5 and 5.6.1.5, it should proceed as follows:
{408, 0} If the UE is in NB-S1 mode, if lower layers cannot find a suitable NB-IoT cell connected to 5GCN or there is no suitable NB-IoT cell connected to 5GCN which supports CIoT 5GS optimizations that are supported by the UE, the UE may re-enable the E-UTRA capability, and indicate to lower layers to remain camped in E-UTRA connected to EPC of the previously registered PLMN and proceed with the appropriate EMM procedure.
---

{407, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability upon receiving reject cause #31 "Redirection to 5GCN required" as specified in subclauses 5.5.1.2.5, 5.5.1.3.5, 5.5.3.2.5, 5.5.3.3.5 and 5.6.1.5, it should proceed as follows:
{412, 0} If the UE is in WB-S1 mode, if lower layers do not provide an indication that the current E-UTRA cell is connected to 5GCN or lower layers do not provide an indication that the current E-UTRA cell supports CIoT 5GS optimizations that are supported by the UE, search for a suitable E-UTRA cell connected to 5GCN according to 3GPP TS 36.304 [21];
---

{407, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability upon receiving reject cause #31 "Redirection to 5GCN required" as specified in subclauses 5.5.1.2.5, 5.5.1.3.5, 5.5.3.2.5, 5.5.3.3.5 and 5.6.1.5, it should proceed as follows:
{412, 0} If the UE is in WB-S1 mode, if lower layers provide an indication that the current E-UTRA cell is connected to 5GCN and the current E-UTRA cell supports CIoT 5GS optimizations that are supported by the UE, then perform a core network selection to select 5GCN as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54] subclause 4.8.4A.1;
---

{407, 0} When the UE is disabling the E-UTRA capability upon receiving reject cause #31 "Redirection to 5GCN required" as specified in subclauses 5.5.1.2.5, 5.5.1.3.5, 5.5.3.2.5, 5.5.3.3.5 and 5.6.1.5, it should proceed as follows:
{412, 0} If the UE is in WB-S1 mode, if lower layers cannot find a suitable E-UTRA cell connected to 5GCN or there is no suitable E-UTRA cell connected to 5GCN which supports CIoT 5GS optimizations that are supported by the UE, the UE may re-enable the E-UTRA capability, and indicate to lower layers to remain camped in E-UTRA connected to EPC of the previously registered PLMN and proceed with the appropriate EMM procedure.
---

{416, 0} The UE shall re-enable the E-UTRA capability when performing a PLMN selection unless, the disabling of E-UTRA capability was due to UE initiated detach procedure for EPS services only;
---

{416, 0} The UE shall re-enable the E-UTRA capability when performing a PLMN selection unless, the UE has already re-enabled the E-UTRA capability when performing bullets b
---

{419, 0} If due to handover, the UE moves to a new PLMN in A/Gb, Iu, or N1 mode which is not in the list of equivalent PLMNs and not a PLMN memorized by the UE for which E-UTRA capability was disabled, and the disabling of E-UTRA capability was not due to UE initiated detach procedure for EPS services only, the UE shall re-enable the E-UTRA capability after the RR/RRC connection is released.
---

{420, 0} If UE that has disabled its E-UTRA capability due to IMS voice not available and CS fallback not available re-enables it when PLMN selection is performed, then it should memorize the identity of the PLMNs where E-UTRA capability was disabled and use that stored information in subsequent PLMN selections as specified in 3GPP TS 23.122 [6].
---

{421, 0} If the "E-UTRA Disabling Allowed for EMM cause #15" parameter as specified in 3GPP TS 24.368 [15A] or 3GPP TS 31.102 [17] is present and set to enabled and if the UE receives an ATTACH REJECT or TRACKING AREA UPDATE REJECT message including both EMM cause #15 "no suitable cells in tracking area" and an Extended EMM cause IE with value "E-UTRAN not allowed", then the UE shall disable the E-UTRA capability, memorize the identity of the PLMN where the E-UTRA capability was disabled and use that stored information in subsequent PLMN selections as specified in 3GPP TS 23.122 [6].
---

{422, 0} When the UE supporting the A/Gb and/or Iu mode together with the S1 mode needs to stay in A/Gb or Iu mode, in order to prevent unwanted handover or cell reselection from UTRAN/GERAN to E-UTRAN, the UE shall disable the E-UTRA capability and:
{423, 0} The UE shall not set the E-UTRA support bits of the MS Radio Access capability IE, the E-UTRA support bits of Mobile Station Classmark 3 IE, the PS inter-RAT HO from GERAN to E-UTRAN S1 mode capability bit and the ISR support bit of the MS network capability IE in the ATTACH REQUEST message and the ROUTING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message after it selects GERAN or UTRAN;
---

{422, 0} When the UE supporting the A/Gb and/or Iu mode together with the S1 mode needs to stay in A/Gb or Iu mode, in order to prevent unwanted handover or cell reselection from UTRAN/GERAN to E-UTRAN, the UE shall disable the E-UTRA capability and, the UE shall use the same value of the EPC capability bit of the MS network capability IE in the ATTACH REQUEST message and the ROUTING AREA UPDATE REQUEST message;
---

{422, 0} When the UE supporting the A/Gb and/or Iu mode together with the S1 mode needs to stay in A/Gb or Iu mode, in order to prevent unwanted handover or cell reselection from UTRAN/GERAN to E-UTRAN, the UE shall disable the E-UTRA capability and, the UE NAS layer shall indicate the access stratum layer of disabling of the E-UTRA capability.
---

{426, 0} When the UE supporting N1 mode together with S1 mode needs to stay in N1 mode, in order to prevent unwanted handover or cell reselection from NG-RAN to E-UTRAN, the UE shall disable the E-UTRA capability and, the UE shall set the S1 mode bit to "S1 mode not supported" in the 5GMM Capability IE of the REGISTRATION REQUEST message;
---

{426, 0} When the UE supporting N1 mode together with S1 mode needs to stay in N1 mode, in order to prevent unwanted handover or cell reselection from NG-RAN to E-UTRAN, the UE shall disable the E-UTRA capability and, the UE shall not include the S1 UE network capability IE in the REGISTRATION REQUEST message;
---

{426, 0} When the UE supporting N1 mode together with S1 mode needs to stay in N1 mode, in order to prevent unwanted handover or cell reselection from NG-RAN to E-UTRAN, the UE shall disable the E-UTRA capability and, the UE NAS layer shall indicate the access stratum layer of disabling of the E-UTRA capability.
---

{430, 0} If the UE is disabling its E-UTRA capability before selecting to GERAN, UTRAN or NG-RAN radio access technology, the UE shall not perform the detach procedure of subclause 5.5.2.1.
---

{431, 0} If the UE is required to disable the E-UTRA capability and select GERAN, UTRAN or NG-RAN radio access technology, and the UE is in the EMM-CONNECTED mode, if the UE has a persistent EPS bearer context and the ongoing prodedure is not a detach procedure, then the UE shall wait until the radio bearer associated with the persistent EPS bearer context has been released;
---

{431, 0} If the UE is required to disable the E-UTRA capability and select GERAN, UTRAN or NG-RAN radio access technology, and the UE is in the EMM-CONNECTED mode, otherwise, the UE shall locally release the established NAS signalling connection and enter the EMM-IDLE mode before selecting GERAN, UTRAN or NG-RAN radio access technology.
---

{434, 0} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to the attempt to select GERAN or UTRAN radio access technology progressing the CS emergency call establishment, the criteria to enable the E-UTRA capability again is UE implementation specific.
---

{435, 0} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to the UE initiated detach procedure for EPS services only, upon request of the upper layers to re-attach for EPS services the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability again.
---

{435, 0} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to the UE initiated detach procedure for EPS services only, upon request of the upper layers to re-attach for EPS services the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability again.
{435, 1} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to receipt of EMM cause #14 "EPS services not allowed in this PLMN", then the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability when the UE powers off and powers on again or the USIM is removed.
---

{435, 0} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to the UE initiated detach procedure for EPS services only, upon request of the upper layers to re-attach for EPS services the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability again.
{435, 1} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to receipt of EMM cause #14 "EPS services not allowed in this PLMN", then the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability when the UE powers off and powers on again or the USIM is removed.
{435, 2} If E-UTRA capability was disabled for any other reason, the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability in, the UE mode of operation changes from CS/PS mode 1 of operation to CS/PS mode 2 of operation;
---

{435, 0} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to the UE initiated detach procedure for EPS services only, upon request of the upper layers to re-attach for EPS services the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability again.
{435, 1} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to receipt of EMM cause #14 "EPS services not allowed in this PLMN", then the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability when the UE powers off and powers on again or the USIM is removed.
{435, 2} If E-UTRA capability was disabled for any other reason, the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability in, the UE mode of operation changes from PS mode 1 of operation to PS mode 2 of operation;
---

{435, 0} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to the UE initiated detach procedure for EPS services only, upon request of the upper layers to re-attach for EPS services the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability again.
{435, 1} If the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to receipt of EMM cause #14 "EPS services not allowed in this PLMN", then the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability when the UE powers off and powers on again or the USIM is removed.
{435, 2} If E-UTRA capability was disabled for any other reason, the UE shall enable the E-UTRA capability in, the UE powers off and powers on again or the USIM is removed;
---

{439, 0} As an implementation option, the UE may start a timer for enabling E-UTRA when the UE's attach attempt counter or tracking area updating attempt counter reaches 5 and the UE disables E-UTRA capability for cases described in subclauses 5.5.1.2.6, 5.5.1.3.4.3, 5.5.1.3.6, 5.5.3.2.6, 5.5.3.3.4.3 and 5.5.3.3.6.
---

{439, 0} As an implementation option, the UE may start a timer for enabling E-UTRA when the UE's attach attempt counter or tracking area updating attempt counter reaches 5 and the UE disables E-UTRA capability for cases described in subclauses 5.5.1.2.6, 5.5.1.3.4.3, 5.5.1.3.6, 5.5.3.2.6, 5.5.3.3.4.3 and 5.5.3.3.6.
{439, 1} The UE should memorize the identity of the PLMNs where E-UTRA capability were disabled.
---

{439, 0} As an implementation option, the UE may start a timer for enabling E-UTRA when the UE's attach attempt counter or tracking area updating attempt counter reaches 5 and the UE disables E-UTRA capability for cases described in subclauses 5.5.1.2.6, 5.5.1.3.4.3, 5.5.1.3.6, 5.5.3.2.6, 5.5.3.3.4.3 and 5.5.3.3.6.
{439, 1} The UE should memorize the identity of the PLMNs where E-UTRA capability were disabled.
{439, 2} On expiry of this timer, if the UE is in Iu mode or A/Gb mode and is in idle mode as specified in 3GPP TS 24.008 [13] on expiry of the timer, the UE should enable the E-UTRA capability;
---

{439, 0} As an implementation option, the UE may start a timer for enabling E-UTRA when the UE's attach attempt counter or tracking area updating attempt counter reaches 5 and the UE disables E-UTRA capability for cases described in subclauses 5.5.1.2.6, 5.5.1.3.4.3, 5.5.1.3.6, 5.5.3.2.6, 5.5.3.3.4.3 and 5.5.3.3.6.
{439, 1} The UE should memorize the identity of the PLMNs where E-UTRA capability were disabled.
{439, 2} On expiry of this timer, if the UE is in Iu mode or A/Gb mode and an RR connection exists, the UE shall delay enabling E-UTRA capability until the RR connection is released;
---

{439, 0} As an implementation option, the UE may start a timer for enabling E-UTRA when the UE's attach attempt counter or tracking area updating attempt counter reaches 5 and the UE disables E-UTRA capability for cases described in subclauses 5.5.1.2.6, 5.5.1.3.4.3, 5.5.1.3.6, 5.5.3.2.6, 5.5.3.3.4.3 and 5.5.3.3.6.
{439, 1} The UE should memorize the identity of the PLMNs where E-UTRA capability were disabled.
{439, 2} On expiry of this timer, if the UE is in Iu mode and a PS signalling connection exists but no RR connection exists, the UE may abort the PS signalling connection before enabling E-UTRA capability;
---

{439, 0} As an implementation option, the UE may start a timer for enabling E-UTRA when the UE's attach attempt counter or tracking area updating attempt counter reaches 5 and the UE disables E-UTRA capability for cases described in subclauses 5.5.1.2.6, 5.5.1.3.4.3, 5.5.1.3.6, 5.5.3.2.6, 5.5.3.3.4.3 and 5.5.3.3.6.
{439, 1} The UE should memorize the identity of the PLMNs where E-UTRA capability were disabled.
{439, 2} On expiry of this timer, if the UE is in N1 mode and is in 5GMM-IDLE mode as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], on expiry of the timer, the UE should enable the E-UTRA capability;
---

{439, 0} As an implementation option, the UE may start a timer for enabling E-UTRA when the UE's attach attempt counter or tracking area updating attempt counter reaches 5 and the UE disables E-UTRA capability for cases described in subclauses 5.5.1.2.6, 5.5.1.3.4.3, 5.5.1.3.6, 5.5.3.2.6, 5.5.3.3.4.3 and 5.5.3.3.6.
{439, 1} The UE should memorize the identity of the PLMNs where E-UTRA capability were disabled.
{439, 2} On expiry of this timer, if the UE is in N1 mode and is in 5GMM-CONNECTED mode as specified in 3GPP TS 24.501 [54], on expiry of the timer, the UE shall delay enabling the E-UTRA capability until the N1 NAS signalling connection is released.
---

{445, 0} If the UE attempts to establish an emergency bearer service in a PLMN where the E-UTRA capability was disabled due to the UE's attach attempt counter or tracking area updating attempt counter have reached 5, the UE may enable the E-UTRA capability for that PLMN memorized by the UE.
---

{446, 0} For other cases, it is up to the UE implementation when to enable the E-UTRA capability.
---

{452, 0} A UE in NB-S1 mode shall calculate the value of the applicable NAS timer, indicated in table 10.2.1 plus 240s;
---

{452, 0} A UE in NB-S1 mode shall calculate the value of the applicable NAS timer, indicated in table 10.3.1 plus 180s.
---

{455, 0} The timer value obtained is used as described in the appropriate procedure subclause of this specification.
---

{455, 0} The timer value obtained is used as described in the appropriate procedure subclause of this specification.
{455, 1} The NAS timer value shall be calculated at start of a NAS procedure and shall not re-calculate the use of the NAS timer value until the NAS procedure is completed, restarted or aborted.
---

{456, 0} When an MME that supports NB-S1 mode performs NAS signaling with a UE, which is using NB-S1 mode, the MME shall calculate the value of the applicable NAS timer, indicated in table 10.2.2 plus 240s;
---

{456, 0} When an MME that supports NB-S1 mode performs NAS signaling with a UE, which is using NB-S1 mode, the MME shall calculate the value of the applicable NAS timer, indicated in table 10.3.2 plus 180s.
---

{459, 0} The timer value obtained is used as described in the appropriate procedure subclause of this specification.
---

{459, 0} The timer value obtained is used as described in the appropriate procedure subclause of this specification.
{459, 1} The NAS timer value shall be calculated at start of a NAS procedure and shall not re-calculate the use of the NAS timer value until the NAS procedure is completed, restarted or aborted.
---

{488, 0} This clause describes the procedures used for mobility management for EPS services at the radio interface.
---

{489, 0} The main function of the mobility management sublayer is to support the mobility of a user equipment, such as informing the network of its present location and providing user identity confidentiality.
---

{490, 0} A further function of the mobility management sublayer is to provide connection management services to the session management sublayer and the short message services entity of the connection management sublayer.
---

{491, 0} All the EMM procedures described in this clause can only be performed if a NAS signalling connection has been established between the UE and the network.
---

{491, 0} All the EMM procedures described in this clause can only be performed if a NAS signalling connection has been established between the UE and the network.
{491, 1} Else, the EMM sublayer has to initiate the establishment of a NAS signalling connection.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{494, 0} EMM common procedures:
{495, 0} An EMM common procedure can always be initiated whilst a NAS signalling connection exists.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{494, 0} EMM common procedures:
{495, 0} An EMM common procedure can always be initiated whilst a NAS signalling connection exists.
{495, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{496, 0} Initiated by the network:
{497, 0} GUTI reallocation;
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{494, 0} EMM common procedures:
{495, 0} An EMM common procedure can always be initiated whilst a NAS signalling connection exists.
{495, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{496, 0} Initiated by the network, authentication;
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{494, 0} EMM common procedures:
{495, 0} An EMM common procedure can always be initiated whilst a NAS signalling connection exists.
{495, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{496, 0} Initiated by the network, security mode control;
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{494, 0} EMM common procedures:
{495, 0} An EMM common procedure can always be initiated whilst a NAS signalling connection exists.
{495, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{496, 0} Initiated by the network, identification;
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{494, 0} EMM common procedures:
{495, 0} An EMM common procedure can always be initiated whilst a NAS signalling connection exists.
{495, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{496, 0} Initiated by the network:
{501, 0} EMM information.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{502, 0} EMM specific procedures:
{503, 0} At any time only one UE initiated EMM specific procedure can be running.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{502, 0} EMM specific procedures:
{503, 0} At any time only one UE initiated EMM specific procedure can be running.
{503, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{504, 0} Initiated by the UE and used to attach the IMSI in the network for EPS services and/or non-EPS services, and to establish an EMM context and if requested by the UE, a default bearer, attach and combined attach.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{502, 0} EMM specific procedures:
{503, 0} At any time only one UE initiated EMM specific procedure can be running.
{503, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{506, 0} Initiated by the UE and used to attach the IMSI or IMEI for emergency bearer services, and to establish an EMM context and a default bearer to a PDN that provides emergency bearer services, attach.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{502, 0} EMM specific procedures:
{503, 0} At any time only one UE initiated EMM specific procedure can be running.
{503, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{508, 0} Initiated by the UE and used to attach the IMSI or IMEI for access to RLOS, and to establish an EMM context and a default bearer to a PDN connection for RLOS, attach.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{502, 0} EMM specific procedures:
{503, 0} At any time only one UE initiated EMM specific procedure can be running.
{503, 1} The procedures belonging to this type are:
{510, 0} Initiated by the UE or the network and used to detach the IMSI in the network for EPS services and/or non-EPS services and to release an EMM context and all bearers, if any, detach and combined detach.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{502, 0} EMM specific procedures:

{512, 0} Initiated by the UE and used to detach the IMSI in the network for EPS services or non-EPS services and to release an EMM context and all bearers, if any, eCall inactivity procedure.
---

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:

{493, 0} Depending on how they can be initiated, three types of EMM procedures can be distinguished:
{518, 0} EMM connection management procedures:
{519, 0} Initiated by the UE and used to establish a secure connection to the network or to request the resource reservation for sending data, or both, service request.

{518, 0} EMM connection management procedures:
{521, 0} The service request procedure can only be initiated if no UE initiated EMM specific procedure is ongoing.

{599, 0} In order to describe the detailed UE behaviour, the EPS update status pertaining to a specific subscriber is defined.

{603, 0} The last attach or tracking area updating attempt was successful.

{625, 0} At intersystem change from A/Gb or Iu mode to S1 mode when no PDP context is active, if EMM-REGISTERED without PDN connection is not supported by the UE or the MME, the UE shall move to state EMM-DEREGISTERED and state GMM-DEREGISTERED and then initiate an attach procedure.
---

{625, 0} At intersystem change from A/Gb or Iu mode to S1 mode when no PDP context is active, if EMM-REGISTERED without PDN connection is not supported by the UE or the MME, the UE shall move to state EMM-DEREGISTERED and state GMM-DEREGISTERED and then initiate an attach procedure.
{625, 1} If EMM-REGISTERED without PDN connection is supported by the UE and the MME, the UE shall enter substates EMM-REGISTERED.NORMAL-SERVICE and GMM-REGISTERED.NO-CELL-AVAILABLE and initiate a tracking area updating procedure.
---

{626, 0} After successful completion of routing area updating or combined routing area updating and tracking area updating or combined tracking area updating procedures in both S1 mode and A/Gb or Iu mode, if the network has indicated that ISR is activated, the UE shall maintain registration and related periodic update timers in both GMM and EMM.
---

{628, 0} UEs that operate in CS/PS mode 1 or CS/PS mode 2 of operation shall use the combined EPS/IMSI attach procedure in order to attach to both EPS and non-EPS services.
---

{629, 0} UEs that operate in CS/PS mode 1 or CS/PS mode 2 of operation and are already attached to both EPS and non-EPS services shall use the combined tracking area updating and periodic tracking area updating procedures.
---

{630, 0} UEs that operate in CS/PS mode 1 or CS/PS mode 2 of operation and are already attached to both EPS and non-EPS services shall perform a combined detach procedure in order to detach for non-EPS services.
---

{631, 0} UEs that operate in CS/PS mode 1 or CS/PS mode 2 of operation should not use any MM timers related to MM specific procedures while camped on E-UTRAN, unless the re-activation of these timers is explicitly described.
---

{631, 0} UEs that operate in CS/PS mode 1 or CS/PS mode 2 of operation should not use any MM timers related to MM specific procedures while camped on E-UTRAN, unless the re-activation of these timers is explicitly described.
{631, 1} If the MM timers are already running, the UE should not react on the expiration of the timers.

{632, 0} If the UE is configured for eCall only mode as specified in 3GPP TS 31.102 [17] and moves from GERAN/UTRAN to E-UTRAN, the UE shall, if timer T3242 is running, start timer T3444 with the time left on T3242 and stop timer T3242;
---

{632, 0} If the UE is configured for eCall only mode as specified in 3GPP TS 31.102 [17] and moves from GERAN/UTRAN to E-UTRAN, the UE shall, if timer T3243 is running, start timer T3445 with the time left on T3243 and stop timer T3243;
